editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The staple of news. A comedy acted in the year, 1625. By his majesty's servants.

quote.l: Aut prodesse volunt, aut delectare poetae:
Aut simul et iucunda, et idonea dicere vitae

div.p: London, printed by I. B. for Robert allot, and are to be sold at the sign of the bear, in Paul's churchyard. 1631.

list.item: Peniboy. the son, the heir and suitor.
Cymbal. Master of the staple, and prime jeerer.
Almanach doctor in physic, and jeerer.
Picklock. Man of law, and emissary Westminster.
Pyed-mantle. Pursuivant at arms, and heraldet.
Register. Of the staple, or office.
Nathaneel. First clerk of the office.
Tho. Barbr. Second clerk of the office.
Broker. Secretary, and gentleman usher to her grace.
Lickfinger. A master cook, and parcel poet.
Fashioner. The tailor of the times.

div.head: The induction.
div.stage: The prologue enters. After him, gossip Mirth. gos. Tatle. gos. Expectation. and gossip censure. 4. Gentlewomen ladylike attired.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: For your own sake, not ours —

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Come gossip, be not ashamed. The play is the staple of news, and you are the mistress, and lady of Tatle, let's ha' your opinion of it: do you hear gentleman? what are you? Gentleman-usher to the play? pray you help us to some stools here.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Yes, of the stage; we are persons of quality, I assure you, and women of fashion; and come to see, and to be seen: my gossip Tatle here, and gossip expectation, and my gossip censure, and I am mirth, the daughter of Christmas, and spirit of Shrovetide. They say, it's merry when gossips meet, I hope your play will be a merry one!

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Or you will make it such, ladies. Bring a form here, but what will the noblemen think, or the grave wits here, to see you seated on the bench thus?

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Why, what should they think? but that they had mothers, as we had, and those mother's had gossips (If their children were christened) as we are, and such as had a longing to see plays, and sit upon them, as we do, and arraign both them, and their poets.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: O! is that your purpose? Why, Mrs. mirth, and madam Tatle, enjoy your delights freely.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: Look your news be new, and fresh, Mr. prologue, and untainted, I shall find them else, if they be stale, or fly-blown, quickly!

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: We ask no favour from you, only we would entreat of madam expectation —

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: That your ladyship would expect no more than you understand.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: I fear too much, lady, and teach others to do the like?

sp.speaker: Expectation.
sp.p: I can do that too, if I have cause.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, you never did wrong, but with just cause. What's this, lady?

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: O curiosity! you come to see, who wears the new suit today? whose clothes are best penned, whatever the part be? which actor has the best leg and foot? what King plays without cuffs? and his Queen without gloves? who rides post in stockings? and dances in boots?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yes, and which amorous prince makes love in drink, or does overact prodigiously in beaten satin, and, having got the trick on't, will be monstrous still, in despite of counsel!

sp.speaker: Book-holder.
sp.p: the tire-men enter to mend the lights.mend your lights, gentlemen. Master prologue, begin.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: Nay, start not ladies, these carry no fireworks to fright you, but a torch i' their hands, to give light to the business. The truth is, there are a set of gamesters within, in travail of a thing called a play, and would fain be delivered of it: and they have entreated me to be their man-midwife, the prologue; for they are like to have a hard labour on't.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: Then the poet has abused himself, like an ass, as he is.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: No, his actors will abuse him enough, or I am deceived. Yonder he is within (I was i' the tiring-house a while to see the actors dressed) rolling himself up and down like a tun, i' the midst of 'em, and spurges, never did vessel of wort, or wine work so! His sweating put me in mind of a good shroving dish (And I believe would be taken up for a service of state somewhere, an't were known) a stewed poet ▪ he doth sit like an unbraced drum with one of his heads beaten out: for, that you must note, a poet hath two heads, as a drum has, one for making, the other repeating, and his repeating head is all to pieces: they may gather it up i' the tiring-house; for he hath torn the book in a poetical fury, and put himself to silence in dead sack, which, were there no other vexation, were sufficient to make him the most miserable emblem of patience.

div.head: The prologue for the stage.
div.l: For your own sakes, not his, he bade me say,
Would you were come to hear, not see a play.
Though we his actors must provide for those,
Who are our guests, here, in the way of shows,
The maker hath not so; he'd have you wise,
Much rather by your ears, then by your eyes:
And prays you'll not prejudge his play for ill,
Because you mark it not, and sit not still;
But have a longing to salute, or talk
With such a female, and from her to walk
With your discourse, to what is done, and where,
How, and by whom, in all the town; but here.
Alas! what is it to his scene, to know
How many coaches in Hyde-park did show
Last spring, what fare today at medleys was,
If Dunstan, or the phoenix best wine has?
They are things — but yet, the stage might stand as well,
If it did neither hear these things, nor tell.
Great noble wits, be good unto yourselves,
And make a difference 'twixt poetic elves,
And poets: all that dabble in the ink,
And defile quills, are not those few, can think,
Conceive, express, and steer the souls of men,
As with a rudder, round thus, with their pen.
He must be one that can instruct your youth,
And keep your acme in the state of truth,
Must enterprise this work, mark but his ways,
What flight he makes, how new; and than he says,
If that not like you, that he sends tonight ,
'Tis you have left to judge, not he to write ▪

div.head: The prologue for the court.
div.l: A work not smelling of the lamp, tonight ,
But fitted for your majesty's disport,
And writ to the meridian of your court,
We bring; and hope it may produce delight:
The rather, being offered, as a rite
To scholars, that can judge, and fair report
The sense they hear, above the vulgar sort
Of nutcrackers, that only come for sight.
Wherein, although our title, sir, be news.
We yet adventure, here, to tell you none;
But show you common follies, and so known,
That though they are not truths, th'innocent muse
Hath made so like, as phantasy could them state,
Or poetry, without scandal, imitate.

div.head: Act. i. scene. i.
div.stage: Peniboy. Iv. lether-legge.

sp.l: Gramercy Letherleg: get me the spurrier,his shoemaker has pulled on a new pair of boots; and he walks in his gown, waistcoat, and trousers, expecting his tailor.
And thou hast fitted me.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Look to me, wit, and look to my wit, land,
That is, look on me, and with all thine eyes,
Male, female, yea, hermaphroditic eyes,
And those bring all your helps, and perspicills,
To see me at best advantage, and augment
My form as I come forth, for I do feel
I will be one, worth looking after, shortly.
Now, by and by, that's shortly. he draws forth his watch, and sets it on the table. 't strikes! One, two,
Three, four, five, six. Enough, enough, dear watch,
Thy pulse hath beaten enough. Now sleep, and rest;
Would thou couldst make the time to do so too:
I'll wind thee up no more. The hour is come
So long expected! There, there,he throws off his gown drop my wardship,
My pupil age, and vassalage together.
And liberty, come throw thyself about me,
In a rich suit, cloak, hat, and band, for now
I'll sue out no man's livery, but mine own,
I stand on my own feet, so much a year,
Right, round, and sound, the lord of mine own ground,
And (To rhyme to it) threescore thousand pound!
he goes to the door, and looks. not come? Not yet? Taylor thou art a vermin,
Worse than the same thou prosecutest, and prickest
In subtle seam — (Go too, I say no more)
thus to retard my longings: on the day
I do write man, to beat thee. One and twenty,
Since the clock struck, complete! and thou wilt feel it
Thou foolish animal! I could pity him,
(An' I were not heartily angry with him now)
For this one piece of folly he bears about him,
To dare to tempt the fury of an heir,
To above two thousand a year; yet hope his custom!
Well, Mr. fashioner, there's some must break —
A head, for this your breaking. Are you come, sir,

div.head: Act. ii. scene. Ij.
div.stage: Fashioner. Peniboy. Thomas Barber. Haberdasher.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What? of your staying?
And leaving me to stalk here in my trowses,
Like a tame hearnshaw for you?

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: I but waited
Below, till the clock struck.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Why, if you had come
Before a quarter, would it so have hurt you,
In reputation, to have waited here?

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: No, but your worship might have pleaded nonage,
If you had got 'em on, ere I could make
Just affidavit of the time.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: That jest
Has gained thy pardon, thou hadst lived, condemned
To thine own hell else, never to have wrought
Stitch more for me, or any Peniboy,
I could have hindered thee: but now thou art mine.
For one and twenty years, or for three lives,
Choose which thou wilt, I'll make thee a copyholder,
he says his suit. and thy first bill unquestioned. Help me on.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.p: Presently, sir, I am bound unto your worship.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Thou shalt be, when I have sealed thee a lease of my custom.

sp.speaker: P. in.
sp.l: Who? Thom?
Come in Thom: set thy things upon the board
And spread thy clothes, lay all forth in procinctu,
And tell's what news?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O sir, a staple of news!
Or the new staple, which you please.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: An office, sir, a brave young office set up.
I had forgotten to tell your worship.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: To enter all the news, sir, of the time,

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: And vent it as occasion serves! A place
Of huge commerce it will be!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Pray thee peace,
I cannot abide a talking tailor: let Thom
(He's a barber) by his place relate it,
What is't, an office, Thom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Newly erected
Here in the house, almost on the same floor,
Where all the news of all sorts shall be brought,
And there be examined, and then registered,
And so be issued under the seal of the office,
As staple news; no other news be currant.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Before me, thou speak'st of a brave business, Thom.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: Nay, if you knew the brain that hatched it sir—

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I know thee well enough: give him a loaf, Thom —
Quiet his mouth, that oven will be venting else.
Proceed —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He tells you true sir Mr. Cymbal,
Is master of the office, he projected it,
He lies here i'the house: and the great rooms
He has taken for the office, and set up
His desks and classes, tables and his shelves,

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: He's my customer, and a wit sir, too.
But, he has brave wits under him —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, four emissaries,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Emissaries? stay, there's a fine new word, Thom!
Pray God it signify any thing, what are emissaries?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Men employed outward, that are sent abroad
To fetch in the commodity.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: From all regions
Where the best news are made.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.p: By way of exchange, or trade.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Nay, thou wilt speak —

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.p: My share sir there's enough for both.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Go on then,he gives the tailor leave to talk.
Speak all thou canst: methinks , the ordinaries
Should help them much.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: Sir, they have ordinaries,
And extraordinaries, as many changes,
And variations, as there are points i'the compass.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: But the 4. Cardinal quarters —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Ay, those Thom —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: The court, sir, Paul's, exchange, and Westminster-hall.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Who is the chief? which hath precedency?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The governor o'the staple, master Cymbal.
He is the chief; and after him the emissaries:
First emissary court, one master Fitton,
He's a jeerer too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Or half a wit, some of them are halfe-wits,
Two to a wit, there are a set of 'em.
Then master Ambler, emissary Paul's,
A fine paced gentleman, as you shall see, walk
The middle I'll: and then my froy Hans Buz,
A Dutchman; he's emissary exchange.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.p: I had thought Mr. Burst the merchant had had it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No,
He has a rupture, he has sprung a leak,
emissary westminster's undisposed of yet;
Then the examiner, register, and two clerks,
They manage all at home, and sort, and file,
And seal the news, and issue them.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thom, dear Thom.
What may my means do for thee, ask, and have it,
I'd fain be doing some good. It is my birthday.
And I'd do it betimes, I feel a grudging
Of bounty, and I would not long lie fallow.
I pray thee think, and speak, or wish for something.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I would I had but one of the clerk's places,
I'this news office,.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thou shalt have it, Thom,
If silver, or gold will fetch it; what's the rate?
At what is't set i'the mercat?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: An't were a hundred, Thom, thou shalt not want it.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.p: the tailor leaps, and embraceth him. o noble master!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: How now Aesop's ass!
Because I play with Thom, must I needs run
Into your rude embraces? stand you still, sir;
Clowns fawnings, are a horse's salutations.
How dost thou like my suit, Thom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Mr. Fashioner
Has hit your measures, sir, h'has moulded you,
And made you, as they say.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: No, no, not I,
I am an ass, old Aesop's ass.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Nay, Fashioner,
I can do thee a good turn too, be not musty,
Though thou hast moulded me, as little Thom says,
he draws out his pockets. (I think thou hast put me in mouldy pockets.)

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: As good,
Right Spanish perfume, the lady Estifania's,
They cost twelve pound a pair.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thy bill will say so.
I pray thee tell me, Fashioner, what authors
Thou readest to help thy invention? Italian prints?
Or arras hangings? They are tailors libraries.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: O, though thou art a silkworm!
And dealest in satins and velvets, and rich plushes,
Thou canst not spin all forms out of thyself;
They are quite other things: I think this suit
Has made me wittier, than I was.

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: Believe it sir,
That clothes do much upon the wit, as weather
Does on the brain; and thence comes your proverb;
The tailor makes the man: I speak by experience
Of my own customers. I have had gallants,
Both court and country, would ha' fooled you up
In a new suit, with the best wits, in being,
And kept their speed, as long as their clothes lasted
Handsome, and neat; but then as they grew out
At the elbows again, or had a stain, or spot,
They have sunk most wretchedly.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What thou reportest,
Is but the common calamity, and seen daily;
And therefore you have another answering proverb:
a broken sleeve keeps the arm back,

sp.speaker: Fas.
sp.l: 'Tis true, sir.
And thence we say, that such a one plays at peep-arm.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Do you so? it is wittily said. I wonder, gentlemen,
And men of means will not maintain themselves
Fresher in wit, I mean in clothes, to the highest.
For he that's out of clothes, is out o'fashion,
And out of fashion, is out of countenance,
And out of countenance, is out of wit.
Is not rogue haberdasher come?

sp.speaker: Hab.
sp.l: Yes, here, sir. they are all about him, busy.
I ha' been without this half hour.

sp.speaker: P iu.
sp.l: Give me my hat.
Put on my girdle. Rascal, sits my ruff well?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: ●s this same hat
O'the block passant? Do not answer me,
I cannot stay for an answer. I do feel
The powers of one and twenty, like a tide
Flow in upon me, and perceive an heir,
Can conjure up all spirits in all circles,
Rogue, rascal, slave ▪ give tradesmen their true names,
And they appear to 'em presently.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Come cast my cloak about me, I'll go see,
This office Thom, and be trimmed afterwards.
I'll put thee in possession, my prime work!
God's so ▪ my spurrier! put hem on boy, quickly,his spurrier comes in.
〈…〉 lost my spurs with too much speed.

div.head: Act. i. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Peniboy, canter. to them singing.

sp.l: Good morning to my joy, my jolly Peniboy!
The lord, and the prince of plenty!
I come to see what riches, thou bearest in thy breeches,
The first of thy one and twenty ▪
What, do thy pockets jingle? Or shall we need to mingle
Our strength both of foot and horses!
These fellows look so eager, as if they would beleaguer
An heir in the midst of his forces!
I hope they be no sergeants! That hang upon thy margins.
This rogue has the jowl of a jailor ▪

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: O founder, no such matter, my spurrier, and my hatter,the young Peny-boy answers in tune.
My linen man, and my tailor.
Thou shouldst have been brought in too, shoemaker,
if the time had been longer, and Thom barber.
How dost thou like my company, old Canter?
Do I not muster a brave troop? all billmen?
Present your arms, before my founder here,
This is my founder, this same learned canter!
He brought me the first news of my father's death,
he takes the bills, and puts them up in his pockets. I thank him, and ever since, I call him founder ▪
Worship him, boys, I'll read only the sums.
And pass 'em straight.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: God's so, some ale, and sugar for my founder!
Good bills, sufficient bills, these bills may pass.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: I do not like those paper-squibs, good master.
They may undo your store, I mean, of credit,
And fire your arsenal, if case you do not
In time make good those outerworks, your pockets,
And take a garrison in of some two hundred,
To beat these pioneers off, that carry a mine
Would blow you up, at last. Secure your casamates,
Here master picklock, sir, your man of law,
And learned attorney, has sent you a bag of munition.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Do, I would have your strengths lined, and perfumed
With gold, as well as amber.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: God a mercy,
Come, ad solvendvm, boys! there, there, and there, etc.
he pays all. I look on nothing but totalis.

sp.speaker: P. Ca·
sp.l: See!
The difference 'twixt the covetous, and the prodigal!
"The covetous man never has money! and
" the prodigal will have none shortly!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Ha,
What says my founder? I thank you, I thank you sirs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your worship, and your worships chanter.

sp.speaker: P ca.
sp.l: I say't is nobly done, to cherish shopkeepers,
And pay their bills, without examining thus.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Alas! they have had a pitiful hard time on't,
A long vacation, from their cozening.
Poor rascals, I do do it out of charity.
I would advance their trade again, and have them
Haste to be rich, swear, and forswear wealthily,
What do you stay for, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: To my box sir,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Your box, why, there's an angel, if my spurs
he gives the spurrier, to his box. be not right Rippon.

sp.speaker: Spu.
sp.l: Give me never a penny
If I strike not thorough your bounty with the rowels.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Dost thou want any money founder?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Who, sir ay,
Did I not tell you I was bred i'the mines,
Under sir Bevis Bullion.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: That is true,
I quite forgotten, you mine-men want no money,
Your streets are paved with 't: there, the molten silver
Runs out like cream, on cakes of gold.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: And rubies
do grow like strawberries.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: 'Twere brave being there!
Come Thom, we'll go to the office now.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: News office, the new staple; thou shalt go too,
'Tis here i'the house, on the same floor, Thom. says,
Come, founder, let us trade in ale, and nutmegs.

div.head: Act. i. scene. Iiii.
div.stage: Register. Clerke. Woman.

sp.l: What, are those desks fit now? set forth the table,
The carpet and the chair: where are the news
That were examined last? ha' you filled them up?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not yet, I had no time.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Are those news registered,
That emissary buz sent in last night?
Of Spinola, and his eggs?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That our new emissary
Westminster, gave us, of the golden heir.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Dispatch, that's news indeed, and of importance.
What would you have good woman?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I would have sir,
A groatsworth of any news, I care not what,a countrywoman waits there.
To carry down this Saturday, to our vicar.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: O! you are a butter-woman, ask Nathaniel
The clerk, there.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, I tell her, she must stay
Till emissary exchange, or Paul's send in,
And then I'll fit her.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Do good woman, have patience,
It is not now, as when the captain lived.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You'll blast the reputation of the office,
Now i'the bud, if you dispatch these groats,
So soon: let them attend in name of policy.

div.head: Act. i. scene. V.
div.stage: Peniboy. Cymbal. Fitton. Tho. Barber. Canter.

sp.p: In troth they are dainty rooms; what place is this?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: This is the outer room, where my clerks sit ▪
And keep their sides, the register i'the midst,
The examiner, he sits private there, within,
And here I have my several rolls, and files
Of news by the alphabet, and all put up
Under their heads.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Or news of doubtful credit, as barber's news.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: And tailor's news, porters, and watermen's news,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Whereto, beside the coranto, and Gazetti.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: I have the news of the season.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As vacation news,
Term-news, and christmas-news.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As the reformed news, Protestant news,

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: And pontificial news, of all which several,
The day-bookes, characters, precedents are kept.
Together with the names of special friends —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And men of correspondence i'the country —

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Yes, of all ranks, and all religions. —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Factors, and agents —

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Liegers, that lie out
Through all the shires o'the kingdom.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: This is fine!
And beats a brave relation! but what says
Mercurius Britannicus to this?

sp.speaker: Cym
sp.p: O sir, he gains by't half in half.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay more
I'll stand to't. For, where he was wont to get
In, hungry captains ▪ obscure statesmen.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Fellows
To drink with him in a dark room in a tavern,
And eat a sausage.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: We ha' seen't,

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: As fain,
To keep so many politic pens
Going, to feed the press.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And dish out news,
Were't true, or false.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Now all that charge is saved
The public chronicler.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: How, do you call him there?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: He that has the maidenhead
Of all the books.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Yes, dedicated to him,

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: No more shall be abused, nor country-parsons
of the inquisition, nor busy justices,
Trouble the peace, and both torment themselves,
And their poor ignorant neighbours with inquiries
After the many, and most innocent monsters,
That never came i'th' counties they were charged with.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Why, methinks sir, if the honest common people
Will be abused, why should not they ha' their pleasure,
In the believing lies, are made for them;
As you i'th' office, making them yourselves?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: O sir! it is the printing we oppose.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: We not forbid that any news, be made,
But that 't be printed; for when news is printed,
It leaves sir to be news. while 'tis but written —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Though it be never so false, it runs news still.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: See divers men's opinions! unto some,
The very printing of them, makes them news;
That ha' not the heart to believe any thing,
But what they see in print.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ay, that's an error
Has abused many; but we shall reform it,
As many things beside (We have a hope)
Are crept among the popular abuses.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Nor shall the stationer cheat upon the time,
By buttering over again —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Once, in seven years,
As the age dotes —

sp.speaker: Cym:
sp.l: And grows forgetful o'them,
His antiquated pamphlets, with new dates.
But all shall come from the mint.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fresh and new stamped,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And if a man will assure his news, he may:
Twopence a sheet he shall be warranted,
And have a policy for't.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Sir, I admire
The method of your place; all things within't
Are so digested, fitted, and composed,
As it shows wit had married order.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: The best we could to invite the times.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: It has
Cost sweat, and freezing.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: And some broken sleeps
Before it came to this.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But now it has the shape —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: A most polite neat thing! with all the limbs,
As sense can taste!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: It is sir, though I say it,
As well-begotten a business, and as fairly
Helped to the world.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: You must be a midwife sir!
Or else the son of a midwife! (Pray you pardon me)
Have helped it forth so happily! what news ha' you?
News of this morning? I would fain hear some
Fresh, from the forge (As new as day, as they say.)

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Show him the last roll,
Of emissary westminster's, the heir.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Come nearer, Thom:

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There is a brave young heir
Peny rejoiceth, that he 〈◊〉. is come of age this morning, mr. Peny-boy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: His father died on this day seventh-night.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: At six o'the clock i'the morning, just a week
〈◊〉 ●hom: of it. ere he was one and twenty.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I am here, Thom!
Proceed, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: An old canting beggar
Brought him first news, whom he has entertained,
call in the canter. He gives the clerk. to follow him, since.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Why, you shall see him! Founder,
Come in; no follower, but companion,
I pray thee put him in, friend. There's an angel —
Thou dost not know, he's a wise old fellow,
Though he seem patched thus, and made up of pieces,
Founder, we are in, here, in, i'the news-office!
In this day's roll, already! I do muse
How you came by us sirs!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: One master Picklock
A lawyer, that hath purchased here a place,
This morning, of an emissary under me.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Gave it into th'office,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: My man of law!
He's my attorney, and solicitor too!
A fine pragmatic! what's his place worth?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'Tis as news come, in,

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: And as they are issued. I have the just moiety
For my part: then the other moiety
Is parted into seven. The four emissaries;
Whereof my cousin Fitton here's for court,
Ambler for Paul's, and buz for the exchange,
Picklock, for Westminster, with the examiner,
And register, they have full parts: and then one part
Is under-parted to a couple of clerks;
And there's the just division of the profits!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: There is one desk empty,
But it has many suitors.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Sir, may I
Present one more and carry it, if his parts
Or gifts, (Which you will, call 'em)

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What are your present clerks habilities?
How is he qualified?

sp.speaker: Cym ▪
sp.l: A decayed stationer
He was, but knows news well, can sort and rank 'em.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And for a need can make 'em.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: True Paul's bread,
I'the churchyard.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And this at the west-door,
O'th other side, he's my barber Thom,
A pretty scholar, and a master of arts,
Was made, or went out master of arts in a throng,
At the university; as before, one Christmas,
He got into a masque at court, by his wit,
And the good means of his cithern, holding up thus
For one o'the music, he's a nimble fellow!
And alike skilled in every liberal science,
As having certain snaps of all, a neat,
Quick-vain, in forging news too. I do love him,
And promised him a good turn, and I would do it.
What's your price? the value?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Get in Thom, take possession, I install thee;
Here, tell your money; give thee joy, good Thom;he buys Thom a clerk's place.
And let me hear from thee every minute of news,
While the new staple stands, or the office lasts,
Which I do wish, may never be less for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The emissaries, sir, would speak with you,
And master Fitton, they have brought in news,
Three bale together.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Business calls us off, sir,they take leave of Peny-boy, and canter.
That may concern the office.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Keep me fair, sir,
Still i'your staple, I am here your friend,
On the same floor.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: How dost thou like it, founder?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: All is well,
But that your man of law methinks appears not
In his due time. O! here comes master's worship.

div.head: Act. i. scene. Vi.
div.stage: Picklock. Peniboy. Iv. P. Canter.

sp.l: How does the heir, bright master Peniboy?
Is he awake yet in his one and twenty?
Why, this is better far, than to wear cypress,
Dull smutting gloves, or melancholy blacks,
And have a pair of twelvepenny broad ribbons
Laid out like labels.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I should ha' made shift
To have laughed as heartily in my mourner's hood,
As in this suit, if it had pleased my father
To have been buried, with the trumpeters:

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: The heralds of arms, you mean.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I mean,
All noise, that is superfluous!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: All that idle pomp,
And vanity of a tombstone, your wise father
Did, by his will, prevent. Your worship had —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: A loving and obedient father of him,
I know it: a right, kind-natured man,
To die so opportunely.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: And to settle
All things so well, compounded for your ward ship
the week afore, and left your state entire
Without any charge upon't.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I must needs say,
I lost an officer of him, a good bailiff,
And I shall want him; but all peace be with him,
I will not wish him alive, again; not I,
For all my fortune; give your worship joy
O'your new place, your emissary-ship,
I'the news office.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Know you, why I bought it sir?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: To work for you, and carry a mine
Against the master of it, master Cymbal;
Who hath a plot upon a gentlewoman,
Was once designed for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Your father,
Old master Peniboy, of happy memory,
And wisdom too, as any i'the county,
Careful to find out a fit match for you,
In his own life time (But he was prevented)
Left it in writing in a schedule here,
To be annexed to his will; that you,
His only son, upon his charge, and blessing,
Should take due notice of a gentlewoman,
Sojourning with your uncle, richer Peniboy.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: A Cornish gentlewoman, I do know her,
Mistress, Pecunia Do-all.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: A great lady,
Indeed she is, and not of mortal race,
Infanta of the mines; her grace's grandfather,
Was Duke, and cousin to the King of Ophyr,
The subterranean, let that pass. Her name is,
Or rather, her three names are (For such she is)
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, a great Princess,
Of mighty power, though she live in private
With a contracted family! Her secretary —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: One broker,
And then two gentlewomen; mistress statute,
And mistress band, with wax the chambermaid,
And mother mortgage, the old nurse, two grooms,
Pawn, and his fellow; you have not many to bribe, sir.
The work is feasible, and th'approaches easy,
By your own kindred. Now, sir, Cymbal thinks,
The master here, and governor o'the staple,
By his fine arts, and pomp of his great place
To draw her! He concludes, she is a woman!
And that so soon as she hears of the new office,
She'll come to visit it, as they all have longings
After new sights, and motions! But your bounty,
Person, and bravery must achieve her.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: She is
The talk o'the time ▪ th'adventure o'the age!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: You cannot put yourself upon an action
of more importance.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: All the world are suitors to her.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: All sorts of men, and all professions!

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: You shall have stall-fed doctors, crammed divines
Make love to her, and with those studied
And perfumed flatteries, as no room can stink
More elegant, then where they are.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Well chanted
Old canter thou singest true.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: And (By your leave)
Good masters worship, some of your velvet coat
Make corpulent curtsies to her, till they crack for't.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: There's doctor almanac woos her, one of the jeerers,
A fine physician.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Your sea-captain, shun field,
Gives out he'll go upon the cannon for her.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Though his loud mouthing get him little credit,

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Young master pied mantle, the fine herald
Professes to deliver her through all ages,
From all the Kings, and Queens, that ever were.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: And master Madrigal, the crowned poet
Of these our times, doth offer at her praises
As fair as any, when it shall please Apollo,
That wit and rhyme may meet both in one subject.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: And you to bear her from all these, it will be —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: The peni-boyes to live in't,

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: It is an action you were built for, sir,

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: And none but you can do it.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I'll undertake it,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Fear me not, for since I came
Of mature age, I have had a certain itch
In my right eye, this corner, here, do you see?
To do some work, and worthy of a chronicle.

div.head: The first intermean after the first act.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: How now gossip! how does the play please you?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Very scurvily, methinks , and sufficiently naught.

sp.speaker: Expectation.
sp.p: As a body would wish: here's nothing but a young prodigal, come of age, who makes much of the barber, buys him a place in a new office, i'the air, I know not where, and his man o'law to follow him, with the beggar to boot, and they two help him to a wife.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Ay, she is a proper piece! that such creatures can broke for.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: I cannot abide that nasty fellow, the beggar, if he had been a court-beggar in good clothes; a beggar in velvet, as they say, I could have endured him.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Or a begging scholar in black, or one of these beggarly poets, gossip, that would hang upon a young heir like a horseleech.

sp.speaker: Expec.
sp.p: Or a threadbare doctor of physic, a poor quacksalver.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Ay, these were tolerable beggars, beggars of fashion! you shall see some such anon!

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: I would fain see the fool, gossip, the fool is the finest man to th' company, they say, and has all the wit: he is the very justice of peace o'the play, and can commit whom he will, and what he will, error, absurdity, as the toy takes him, and no man say, black is his eye, but laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: But they ha' no fool i' this play, I am afraid, gossip.

sp.speaker: Expectation.
sp.p: They are all fools, the rather, in that.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: My husband, (Timothy Tatle, God rest his poor soul) was wont to say, there was no play without a fool, and a devil in't; he was for the devil still God bless him. The devil for his money, would he say, I would fain see the devil. And why would you so fain see the devil? would I say. Because he has horns, wife, and may be a cuckold, as well as a devil, he would answer: you are e'en such another, husband, quoth I. Was the devil ever married? where do you read, the Devil was ever so honourable to commit matrimony; the play will tell us, that, says he, we'll go see't tomorrow, the devil is an ass. He is an errant learned man, that made it, and can write, they say, and I am foully deceived, but he can read too.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: I remember it gossip, I went with you, by the same token, Mrs. Trouble truth dissuaded us, and told us, he was a profane poet, and all his plays had devils in them. That he kept school upo'the stage, could conjure there, above the school of Westminster, and doctor lamb too: not a play he made, but had a devil in it. And that he would learn us all to make our husbands cuckolds at plays: by another token, that a young married wife i'the company, said, she could find in her heart to steal thither, and see a little o'the vanity through her mask, and come practice at home.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Nay, gossip, I name nobody . It may be 'twas myself.

sp.speaker: Expectation.
sp.p: But was the devil a proper man, gossip?

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: As fine a gentleman ▪ of his inches, as ever I saw trusted to the stage ▪ or anywhere else: and loved the common wealth, as well as ere a patriot of 'em all: he would carry away the vice on his back, quick to hell, in every play where he came, and reform abuses.

sp.speaker: Expectation.
sp.p: There was the devil of Edmonton, no such man, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: The conjurer cozened him with a candle's end, he was an ass.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: But there was one Smug, a smith, would have made a horse laugh, and broke his halter, as they say.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: O, but the poor man had got a shrewd mischance, one day.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: He had dressed a rogue jade i'the morning, that had the staggers, and had got such a spice of 'em himself, by noon, as they would not away all the play time, do what he could, for his heart.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: 'Twas his part, gossip, he was to be drunk, by his part.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: Say you so, I understood not so much.

sp.speaker: Expecta.
sp.p: Would we had such another part, and such a man in this play, I fear 'twill be an excellent dull thing.

div.head: Act. ii. scene. i.
div.stage: Peniboy. Sen. pecunia. Mortgage. Statute. Band. Broker.

sp.l: Your grace is sad methinks , and melancholy!
You do not look upon me with that face,
As you were wont, my goddess, bright Pecunia:
Although your grace be fallen, of two i'the hundred,
In vulgar estimation; yet am I,
You grace's servant still: and teach this body,
To bend, and these my aged knees to buckle,
In adoration, and just worship of you.
Indeed, I do confess, I have no shape
To make a minion of, but I'm your martyr,
Your grace's martyr. I can hear the rogues,
As I do walk the streets, whisper, and point,
There goes old Peniboy, the slave of money,
Rich Peniboy, lady Pecunia's drudge,
A sordid rascal, one that never made
Good meal in his sleep, but sells the acates are sent him,
Fish, fowl, and venison, and preserves himself,
Like an old hoary rat, with mouldy piecrust.
This I do hear, rejoicing, I can suffer
This, and much more, for your good grace's sake.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Why do you so my guardian? I not bid you,
Cannot my grace be gotten, and held too,
Without your self-tormentings, and your watches,
Your macerating of your body thus
With cares, and scantings of your diet, and rest?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: O, no, your services, my princely lady,
Cannot with too much zeal of rites be done,
They are so sacred.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: But my reputation.
May suffer, and the worship of my family,
When by no servile me●nes they both are sought.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You are a noble, young, free, gracious lady,
And would be everybody's , in your bounty,
But you must not be so. They are a few
That know your merit, lady, and can valew't.
Yourself scarce understands your proper powers.
They are almighty, and that we your servants,
That have the honour here to stand so near you,
Know; and can use too. All this nether-world
Is yours, you command it, and do sway it,
The honour of it, and the honesty,
The reputation, ay, and the religion,
(I was about to say, and had not erred)
Is Queen Pecunia's. For that style is yours,
If mortals knew your grace, or their own good.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: I fear your grace
Hath taken too much of the sharp air.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: O no!
I could endure to take a great deal more
(And with my constitution, were it left)
Unto my choice, what think you of it, statute?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: A little now and then does well, and keeps
Your grace in your complexion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: But too much madam ▪ may increase cold rheums,
Nourish catarrhs, green sicknesses, and agues,
And put you in consumption

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Best to take
Advice of your grave women, noble madam,
They know the state o'your body, and ha' studied
Your grace's health.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: And honour. Here'll be visitants,
Or suitors by and by; and 'tis not fit
They find you here.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: 'Twill make your grace too cheap
To give them audience presently.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Leave your secretary,
To answer them.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I shall madam.
And do your grace's trusts with diligence.

div.head: Act. ii. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Pyed-mantle. Broker. Peniboy. Sen.

sp.l: What luck's this? I am come an inch too late,
Do you hear sir? Is your worship o'the family
Unto the lady Pecunia?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I serve her grace, sir,
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, the infanta.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Has she all those titles, and her grace besides,
I must correct that ignorance and oversight,
Before I do present. Sir, I have drawn
A pedigree for her grace, though yet a novice
In that so noble study.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: No sir, a pursuivant, my name is Pied-mantle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I have deduced her. —

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: From all the Spanish mines in the West-indi'es,
I hope: for she comes that way by her mother,
But, by her grandmother, she's Duchess of mines.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: From man's creation I have brought her.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: No further?
Before sir, long before, you have done nothing else,
Your mines were before Adam, search your office,
Roll five and twenty, you will find it so,
I see you are but a novice, master Pied-mantle.
If you had not told me so.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Sir, an apprentice
In armoury. I have read the elements,
And accidence, and all the leading books,
And I have, now, upon me a great ambition,
How to be brought to her grace, to kiss her hands.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Why, if you have acquaintance with mistress statute,
Or mistress band, my lady's gentlewomen,
They can induce you. One is a judge's daughter,
But somewhat stately; th'other mistress band,
Her father's but a scrivener, but she can
Almost as much with my lady, as the other,
Especially, if Rose wax the chambermaid
Be willing. Do you not know her, sir, neither?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: She's a good pliant wench,
And easy to be wrought, sir, but the nurse
Old mother mortgage, if you have a tenement,
Or such a morsel? though she have no teeth,
she loves a sweet meat, any thing that melts
In her warm gums, she could command it for you
On such a trifle, a toy. Sir, you may see,
How for your love, and this so pure complexion,
(A perfect sanguine) I ha' ventured thus,
The straining of a ward, opening a door
Into the secrets of our family:

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I pray you let me know, sir, unto whom
I am so much beholden; but your name.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: My name is broker, I am secretary,
And usher, to her grace.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Why? you could do me,
If you would, now, this favour of yourself.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Truly, I think I could: but if I would,
I hardly should, without, or mistress band,
Or mistress statute, please to appear in it.
Or the good nurse I told you of, mistress mortgage ▪
We know our places here, we mingle not
One in another's sphere, but all move orderly,
In our own orbs; yet we are all concentricks.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Well, sir, I'll wait a better season.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Do,
And study the right means, get mistress band
Broker makes a mouth at him. He jeers him again. Old Peny-boy leaps to urge on your behalf, or little wax.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I have a hope, sir, that I may, by chance,
Light on her grace, as she's taking the air:

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: That air of hope, has blasted many an airy
Of kestrels like yourself: good master Pied-mantle,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Well said, master secretary, I stood behind
And heard thee all. I honour thy dispatches.
If they be rude, untrained it our method
And have not studied the rule, dismiss 'em quickly,
Where's Lickfinger my cook? that unctuous rascal?
He'll never keep his hour, that vessel of kitchenstuff!

div.head: Act. ii. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Broker. Peny-boy. Se. Lickfinger.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Pox upon him kidney,
Always too late!

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: To wish 'em you, I confess,
That ha'them already.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: The piles,
The plague, and all diseases light on him,
Knows not to keep his word. I'd keep my word sure!
I hate that man that will not keep his word,
When did I break my word?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Or I, till now?
And 'tis but half an hour.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Half a year:
To me that stands upon a minute of time.
I am a just man, I love still to be just.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Why? you think I can run like lightfoot Ralph,
Or keep a wheelbarrow, with a sail in town here,
To whirl me to you: I have lost two stone
Of svet i'the service posting hither,
You might have followed me like a watering pot,
And seen the knots I made along the street;
My face dropped like the skimmer in a fritter pan,
And my whole body, is yet (To say the truth)
A rosted pound of butter, with grated bread in 't! he sweeps his face.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Believe you, he that list. You stayed of purpose,
To have my venison stink, and my foul mortified,
That you might ha' 'em —

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: A shilling or two cheaper,
That's your jealousy.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Perhaps it is.
Will you go in, and view, and value all?
Yonder is venison sent me! foul! and fish!
In such abundance! I am sick to see it!
I wonder what they mean! I ha' told 'em of it!
To burden a weak stomach! and provoke
A dying appetite! thrust a sin upon me
I ne'er was guilty of! nothing but gluttony!
Gross gluttony! that will undo this land!

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Ay, that same's
A crying sin, a fearful damned device,
Eats up the poor, devours 'em —

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Sir, take heed
What you give out.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Against your grave great Solons?
Numae pompilij, they that made that law?
To take away the poor's inheritance?
It was their portion: I will stand to't.
And they have robbed 'em of it, plainly robbed 'em,
I still am a just man, I tell the truth.
When moneys went at ten i'the hundred, ay,
And such as I, the servants of Pecunia,
Could spare the poor two out of ten, and did it,
How say you, Broker?

sp.speaker: (Lic.
sp.l: Ask your echo)

sp.speaker: P. S●..
sp.l: I am for justice, when did I leave justice?
We knew 'twas theirs, they had right and title to't.
Now —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Very little,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: They have bound our hands
With their wise solemn act, shortened our arms.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Beware those worshipful ears, sir, be not shortened,
And you play crop i'the fleet, if you use this licence.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: I am Lickfinger,
Your cook.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: A saucy Jack you are, that's once;
What said I, Broker?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: I know his gift, he can be deaf when he list.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Have you provided me my bushel of eggs?
I did bespeak? I do not care how stale,
Or stinking that they be; let 'em be rotten:
For ammunition here to pelt the boys,
That break my windows?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Yes sir, I ha' spared 'em
Out of the custard politic for you, the majors.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: 'Tis well, go in, take hence all that excess,
Make what you can of it, your best: and when
I have friends, that I invite at home, provide me
Such, such, and such a dish, as I bespeak;
One at a time, no superfluity.
Or if you have it not, return me money;
You know my ways.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: 'Tis true, sir,
I do indent you shall return me money.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: Rather than meat, I know it: you are just still.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: I love it still. And therefore if you spend
The red-deer pies i'your house, or sell 'em forth, sir,
Cast so, that I may have their coffins all,
Returned here, and piled up: I would be thought
To keep some kind of house.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: And then remember meat for my two dogs:
Fat flaps of mutton; kidneys; rumps of veal;
Good plenteous scraps; my maid shall eat the relics.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: When you and your dogs have dined. A sweet reversion.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Who's here? my courtier? and my little doctor?
My muster-master? and what plover's that
They have brought to pull?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I know not, some green plover.
I'll find him out.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Do, for I know the rest,
They are the jeerers, mocking, flouting jacks.

div.head: Act. ii. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Fitton. Peniboy. Se. Almanach. Shunfield. Madrigal. Lickfinger. Broker.

sp.p: How now old money-bawd? we're come —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: To jeer me,
As you were wont, I know you.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: No, to give thee
Some good security, and see Pecunia.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: We'll be one bound for another.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This man of war, he was our muster-master.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: But a sea-captain now, brave captain Shunfield. he holds up his nose.

sp.speaker: Shun.
sp.p: You snuff the air now, as the scent displeased you?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Thou needst not fear him man, his credit is sound,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And seasoned too, since he took salt at sea.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: I do not love pickled security,
Would I had one good freshman in for all;
For truth is, you three stink.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: You are a rogue,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: I think I am, but I will lend no money
On that security, captain.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Here's a gentleman,
A freshman i'the world, one master Madrigal.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Of an untainted credit; what say you to him?

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: He's gone methinks , where is he? Madrigal? Madrigal steps aside with broker.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: He has an odd singing name, is he an heir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: An heir to a fair fortune,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And full hopes:
A dainty scholar, and a pretty poet!

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You've said enough. I ha' no money, gentlemen,
And he go to't in rhyme once, not a penny

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: Why, he's of years, though he have little beard. he snuffs again.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: His beard has time to grow. I have no money:
Let him still dabble in poetry. No Pecunia
Is to be seen.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Come, thou lovest to be costive
Still i' thy curtsy; but I have a pill,
A golden pill to purge away this melancholy.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but his keeping o'the house here,
With his two drowsy dogs.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A drench of sack
At a good tavern, and a fine fresh pullet,
would cure him.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Nothing but a young hair in white-broth,
I know his diet better than the doctor.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: What Lickfinger? mine old host of Ram-alley?
You ha' some mer●at here.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Some dosser of fish
Or fowl to fetch of.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: An odd bargain of venison,
To drive.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: I must needs,
You see who drives me, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fit,
sp.p: He may be in time, he is his agent, now.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You are all cogging jacks, a covey of wits,
The jeerers, that still call together at meals:
Or rather an airy, for you are birds of prey:
Peny-boy thrusts him in. and fly at all, nothing's too big or high for you.
And are so truly feared, but not beloved
One of another: as no one dares break
Company from the rest, lest they should fall,
Upon him absent.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O! the only oracle
That ever peeped, or spoke out of a doublet.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: How the rogue stinks, worse than a fishmonger sleeves!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: His face looks like a dyer's apron, just!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: A sodden head, and his whole brain a possit cured!

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: Ay, now you jeer, jeer on; I have no money.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I wonder what religion he's of!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No certain species sure, a kind of mule!
That's half an ethnic, half a christian!

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: This stock.
He has no sense of any virtue, honour,
Gentry or merit.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You say very right,
My meritorious captain, (As I take it!)
Merit will keep no house, nor pay no house rent.
Will mistress merit go to mercat, think you?
Set on the pot, or feed the family?
Will gentry clear with the butcher? or the baker?
Fetch in a pheasant, or a brace of partridges,
From goodwife Poulter, for my lady's supper.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: This rogue has money though,
My worshipful brave courtier has no money.
No, nor my valiant captain.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Nor you, my learned doctor. I loved you
While you did hold your practice, and kill tripe wives.
And kept you to your urinal; but since your thumbs
Have greased the Ephemerides, casting figures,
And turning over for your candle-rents,
And your twelve houses in the zodiac:
With your almutens, alma cantaras,
Troth you shall cant alone for Peny-boy.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: I told you what we should find him, a mere bawd.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: What you please, gentlemen,
I am of that humble nature and condition,
Never to mind your worships, or take notice
Of what you throw away, thus. I keep house here
Like a lame cobbler, never out of doors,
With my two dogs, my friends; and (As you say)
Drive a quick pretty trade, still. I get money:
And as for titles, be they rogue, or rascal,
Or what your worship's fancy, let 'em pass
As transitory things; they're mine today,
And yours tomorrow.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You see how I do blush, and am ashamed
Of these large attributes? yet you have no money.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Well wolf, hyaena, you old pocky rascal,
You will ha' the hernia fall down again
Into your scrotum, and I shall be sent for.
I will remember then, that; and your fistula
In ano, I cured you of.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Thank your dog-leech craft.
They were 'Wholesome piles, afore you meddled with'em .

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: What an ungrateful wretch is this?

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: He minds
A courtesy no more, than London-bridge,
What arch was mended last.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: He never thinks.
More than a log, of any grace at court,
A man may do him: or that such a lord
Reached him his hand.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: O yes! if grace would strike
The brewer's tally, or my good lords hand,
Would quit the scores. But sir, they will not do it,
Here's a piece, my good lord piece, doth all.
Goes to the butchers ▪ fetches in a mutton,he shows a piece.
Then to the bakers, brings in bread, makes fires,
Gets wine, and does more real courtesies,
Than all my lords, I know: my sweet lord piece!
You are my lord, the rest are cogging jacks,
Under the rose.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Rogue, I could beat you now,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: True captain, if you durst beat any other.
I should believe you, but indeed you are hungry;
You are not angry captain, if I know you
Aright; good captain. No, Pecunia,
Is to be seen, though mistress band would speak,
Or little blushet-wax, be ne'er so easy,
I'll stop mine ears with her, against the Syrens,
Court, and philosophy. God be wi● you, gentlemen,
Provide you better names. Pecunia is for you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: What a damned harpy it is? where's Madrigal?
Is he sneaked hence.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Here he comes with Broker,Madrigal returns.
Pecunia's secretary.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: He may do some good
With him perhaps. Where ha' you been Madrigal?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Above with my lady's women, reading verses.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: That was a favour. Good morrow, master secretary.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Sir, by both
Your worshipful titles, and your name mas. Broker.
Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: I did ask him if he were
Amphibion Broker.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: A creature of two natures,
Because he has two offices.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: You may jeer,
You ha' the wits, young gentlemen. But your hope
Of Helicon, will never carry it, here,
With our fat family; we ha' the dullest,
Most unboared ears for verse amongst our females.
I grieved you read so long, sir, old nurse mortgage,
She snored i'the chair, and statute (If you marked her)
Fell fast asleep , and mistress band, she nodded,
But not with any consent to what you read.
They must have somewhat else to chink, than rhymes.
If you could make an epitaph on your land,
(Imagine it on departure) such a poem
Would wake 'em ▪ and bring wax to her true temper.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: i'faith sir, and I will try.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: 'Tis but earth,
Fit to make bricks and tiles of.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Pocks upon't
'Tis but for pots, or pipkins at the best.
If it would keep us in good tobacco pipes,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Or in porc lane dishes
There were some hope.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: But this is a hungry soil,
And must be helped.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Who would hold any land
To have the trouble to mar'le it.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Let clowns and hinds affect it, that love ploughs,
And carts, and harrows, and are busy still,
In vexing the dull element.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Our sweet songster
Shall rarifie't into air.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And you mass Broker
Shall have a feeling.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: So it supple, sir,
The nerves.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: O! it shall be palpable,
Make thee run thorough a hoop, or a thumb-ring,
The nose of a tobacco pipe, and draw
Thy ductile bones out, like a knitting needle,
To serve my subtle turns.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I shall obey, sir,
And run a thread, like an hourglass.

sp.speaker: P. S●.
sp.l: Where is broker?
Are not these flies gone yet? pray quit my house,
I'll smoke you out else.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O! the prodigal!
Will you be at so much charge with us, and loss?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: I have heard you ha' offered sir, to lock up smoke,
And calk your windows, spar up all your doors,
Thinking to keep it a close prisoner wi'you,
And wept, when it went out, sir, at your chimney.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: And yet his eyes were drier than a pumice.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: A wretched rascal, that will bind about
the nose of his bellows, lest the wind get out
When he's abroad.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Sweeps down no cobwebs here,
But sells 'em for cut-fingers. And the spiders,
As creatures reared of dust, and cost him nothing,
To fat old ladies' monkeys.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: He has offered
To gather up spilt water, and preserve
Each hair falls from him to stop balls with all.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: A slave, and an idolater to Pecunia!

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: You all have happy memories, gentlemen,
In rocking my poor cradle. I remember too,
When you had lands, and credit, worship, friends,
Ay, and could give security: now, you have none,
Or will have none right shortly. This can time,
And the vicissitude of things. I have
All these. and money too, and do possess 'em,
And am right heartily glad of all our memories,
And both the changes.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: He's glad he is rid of his torture, and so soon.
Broker, come hither, up, and tell your lady,
She must be ready presently, and statute,
Band, mortgage, wax. My prodigal young kinsman
Will straight be here to see her 'top of our house,
The flourishing, and flaunting Peny-boy.
We were but three of us in all the world,
My brother Francis, whom they called Frank Peny-boy,
Father to this: he's dead. This Peny-boy,
Is now the heir! Ay, richer Peny-boy,
Not Richard, but old Harry Peny-boy,
And (To make rhyme) close, wary Peny-boy
I shall have all at last, my hopes do tell me.
Go, see all ready; and where my dogs have faulted,
Remove it with a broom, and sweeten all
With a slice of juniper, not too much, but sparing,
We may be faulty ourselves else, and turn prodigal,
In entertaining of the prodigal.
Here he is! and with him — what! A clapper dudgeon!
That's a good sign; to have the beggar follow him,
So near at his first entry into fortune.

div.head: Act. ii. scene. V.
div.stage: Peny-boy. Iv. Peniboy. Sen. Piclock. Canter.) Broker. Pecunia. Statute. Band. Wax. mortgage. hid in the study.

sp.l: How now old uncle? I am come to see thee.
And the brave lady, here, the daughter of Ophir,
They say thou keepest.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Sweet nephew, if she were
The daughter of the sun, she's at your service,
And so am I, and the whole family,
Worshipful nephew.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Sayest thou so, dear uncle?
Welcome my friends then: here is, dominae picklock:
My man o'law, solicits all my causes.
Follows my business, makes, and compounds my quarrels,
Between my tenants and me, sows all my strifes,
And reaps them too, troubles the country for me,
And vexes any neighbour, that I please.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: I thank his worship for it.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: But what is this old gentleman?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: A rogue,
A very canter, I sir, one that mands
Upon the pad, we should be brothers though:
For you are near as wretched as myself,
You dare not use your money, and I have none.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Not use my money, cogging Jack, who uses it
At better rates? lets it for more i'the hundred,
Than I do, sirrah?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: What? to disgrace me, with my Queen? as if
I did not know her value.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Sir, I meant
You durst not to enjoy it.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Hold your peace,
young Peny-boy is angry. you are a jack.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Uncle, he shall be a John,
And, you go to that, as good a man as you are.
An' I can make him so, a better man,
Perhaps I will too. Come, let us go.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Nay, kinsman,
My worshipful kinsman; and the top of our house;
Do not your penitent uncle that affront,
For a rash word, to leave his joyful threshold,
Before you see the lady that you long for.
The Venus of the time, and state, Pecunia!
I do perceive, your bounty loves the man,
〈…〉 concealed virtue, that he hides
Under these ●ags.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: I owe my happiness to him,
The waiting on his worship, since I brought him
〈…〉, welcome to all young heirs.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thou didst indeed, for which I thank thee yet,
Your 〈◊〉 Princess, uncle, is long a coming.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: She is not rigged, sir, setting forth some lady,
Will cost as much as furnishing a fleet,

〈◊〉 she's come at last,
The study is opened where she sit in state.
She kisseth him. and like a galley
〈◊〉 i'the prow.

sp.speaker: P. S●.
sp.l: Vouchsafe my towards kinsman, gracious madam,
The savour of your hand.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Nay, of my lips, sir,
To him.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: She kisses like a mortal creature,
Almighty mad●●e, I have longed to see you.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: And I have my desire, sir, to behold
That youth, and shape, which in my dreams and wakes ▪
I have so oft contemplated, and felt
Warm in my veins, and native as my blood.
When I was told of your arrival here,
I felt my heart beat, as it would leap out,
In speech; and all my face it was a flame,
But how it came to pass I do not know.

sp.speaker: P. I●..
sp.l: O! beauty loves to be more proud than nature,
That made you blush. I cannot satisfy
My curious eyes, by which alone I'm happy,
In my beholding you.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: They pass the compliment
Prettily well.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Ay, he does kiss her, I like him.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: My passion was clear contrary, and doubtful,he kisseth her.
I shook for fear, and yet I danced for joy,
I had such motions as the sunbeams make
Against a wall, or playing on a water,
Or trembling vapour of a boiling pot —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: That's not so good, it should ha' been a crucible,
With molten mettle, she had understood it.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I cannot talk, but I can love you, madam.
Are these your gentlewomen? I love them too.
And which is mistress statute? Mistress band ▪
They all kiss close, the last stuck to my lips.

sp.speaker: B●o.
sp.p: It was my lady's chambermaid, soft-wax.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Soft lips she has, I am sure on't. Mother mortgage,
I' low a kiss ▪ till she be younger, statute,he doubles the compliment to them all.
Sweet mistress band, and honey, little wax,
We must be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.l: But whom her grace is so content to grace,
We shall observe.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: A fine well-spoken family. What's thy name?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Methinks my uncle should not need thee,
Who is a crafty knave, enough, believe it.
Art thou her grace's steward?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What, o'the hall? thou hast a sweeping face,
Thy beard is like a broom.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: No barren chin, sir,
I am no eunuch, though a gentleman-usher.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thou shalt go with us. Uncle, I must have
My Princess forth today.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Whither you please, sir,
You shall command her.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: I will do all grace
To my new servant.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Thanks unto your bounty;
He is my nephew, and my chief, the point,
old Peny-boy thanks her, but makes his condition. tip, top, and tuft of all our family!
But, sir, conditioned always, you return
Statute, and Band home, with my sweet, soft wax,
And my good nurse, here, mortgage.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: She shall go with you,
Whither you please, sir, anywhere .

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: I see
A money-bawd, is lightly a flesh-bawd, too.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Are you advised? Now o'my faith, this canter
Would make a good grave burgess in some barn.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt go with us, uncle.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: We'll have both sack, and fiddlers.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: I'll not draw
That charge upon your worship.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: He speaks modestly,
And like an uncle,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: But mas. Broker, here,
He shall attend you, nephew; her grace's usher,
And what you fancy to bestow on him,
Be not too lavish, use a temperate bounty,
I'll take it to myself.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I will be princely,
While I possess my Princess, my Pecunia.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Hard by, at Picklocks lodging.
Old lickfinger's the cook, here in Ram-alley.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: He has good cheer; perhaps I'll come and see you.

sp.speaker: P. can.
sp.l: O, fie! an alley, and a cooks-shop, gross,
the canter takes him aside, and persuades him, 't will savour, sir, most rankly of 'em both.
Let your meat rather follow you, to a tavern.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: A tavern's as unfit too, for a Princess.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: No, I have known a Princess, and a great one,
Come forth of a tavern.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: She must go in, if she came forth: the blessed
Pokahontas (As the historian calls her
And great Kings daughters of Virginia)
Hath been in womb of a tavern; and besides,
Your nasty uncle will spoil all your mirth,
And be as noisome.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: No i'faith,
Dine in Apollo with Pecunia,
At brave Duke Wadloo's, have your friends about you,
And make a day on't.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Content i'faith:
our meat shall be brought thither. Simon the King,
Will bid us welcome.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: That you will carry the infanta,
To see the staple , her grace will be a grace,
To all the members of it.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I will do it:
And have her arms set up there, with her titles,
Aurelia Clara Pecunia, the infanta.
And in Apollo. Come (Sweet Princess) go.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: Broker, be careful of your charge.

div.head: The second intermean after the second act.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Why, this is duller and duller! intolerable! scurvy! neither devil nor fool in this play! pray God, some on us be not a witch, gossip, to forespeak the matter thus.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: I fear we are all such, and we were old enough: but we are not all old enough to make one witch. How like you the vice i'the play.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Three or four: old covetousness, the sordid Peny-boy, the money-bawd, who is a flesh-bawd too, they say.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: But here is never a fiend to carry him away. Besides, he has never a wooden dagger! I'd not give a rush for a vice, that has not a wooden dagger to snap at everybody he meets.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: That was the old way, gossip, when iniquity came in like hocus-pocus , in a jugglers's jerkin, with false skirts ▪ like the knave of clubs! but now they are attired like men and women of the time, the vices, male and female! Prodigality like a young heir, and his mistress money (Whose favours he scatters like counters) pranked up like a prime lady, the infanta of the mines.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Ay, therein they abuse an honourable Princess, it is thought.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: By whom is it so thought? or where lies the abuse?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Plain in the styling her infanta, and giving her three names.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Take heed, it lie not in the vice of your interpretation: what have Aurelia, Clara, Pecunia to do with any person? do they any more, but express the property of money, which is the daughter of earth, and drawn out of the mines? Is there nothing to be called infanta, but what is subject to exception? Why not the infanta of the beggars? or infanta o'the Gipsies? as well as King of beggars, and King of Gipsies?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Well, and there were no wiser than I, I would sow him in a sack, and send him by sea to his Princess.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Faith, and he heard you censure, he would go near to stick the ass's ears to your high dressing, and perhaps to all ours for harkening to you.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: By'r lady but he should not to mine, I would hearken, and hearken, and censure, if I saw cause, for th'other Princess' sake Pokahontas, surnamed the blessed, whom he has abused indeed (And I do censure him, and will censure him) to say she came forth of a tavern, was said like a paltry poet.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: That's but one gossip's opinion, and my gossip Tatle's too! but what says expectation, here, she sits sullen and silent.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Troth I expect their office, their great office! the staple, what it will be! they have talked on't, but we see't not open yet; would butter would come in, and spread itself a little to us.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Or the butterbox, buz, the emissary.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: When it is churned, and dished, we shall hear of it.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: If it be fresh and sweet butter; but say it be sour and wheyish.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Then it is worth nothing, mere pot-butter, fit to be spent in suppositories, or greasing coach-wheels, stale stinking butter, and such I fear it is, by the being barrelled up so long.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Have patience gossips, say that contrary to our expectations it prove right, seasonable, salt butter.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Or to the time of year, in lent, delicate almond butter! I have a sweet tooth yet, and I will hope the best; and sit down as quiet, and calm as butter; look as smooth, and soft as butter; be merry, and melt like butter; laugh and be fat like butter: so butter answer my expectation, and be not mad butter; if it be: it shall both July and December see. I say no more, but — Dixi.

div.head: To the readers.
div.p: In this following act, the office is opened, and shown to the prodigal, and his Princess Pecunia, wherein the allegory, and purpose of the author hath hitherto been wholly mistaken, and so sinister an interpretation been made, as if the souls of most of the spectators had lived in the eyes and ears of these ridiculous gossips that tattle between the acts. But he prays you thus to mend it. To consider the news here vented, to be none of his news, or any reasonable man's; but news made like the time's news, (A weekly cheat to draw money) and could not be fitter reprehended, then in raising this ridiculous office of the staple, wherein the age may see her own folly, or hunger and thirst after published pamphlets of news, set out every Saturday, but made all at home, and no syllable of truth in them: than which there cannot be a greater disease in nature, or a fouler scorn put upon the times. And so apprehending it, you shall do the author, and your own judgement a courtesy, and perceive the trick of alluring money to the office, and there cozening the people. If you have the truth, rest quiet, and consider that
div.quote: Ficta, voluptatis causa, sint proxima veris.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. i.
div.stage: Fitton. Cymbal, to them Picklock. Register. Clerke. Tho. Barber.

sp.l: Ye hunt upon a wrong scent still, and think
The air of things will carry 'em, but it must
Be reason and proportion, not fine sounds,
My cousin Cymbal, must get you this lady.
You have entertained a pettifogger here,
Picklock, with trust of an emissary's place,
And he is, all, for the young prodigal,
You see he has left us.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Come, you do not know him,
That speak thus of him. He will have a trick,
To open us a gap ▪ by a trap-door,
When they least dream on't. Here he comes. What news?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.l: Where is my brother buz? my brother Ambler:
The register, examiner, and the clerks?
Appear, and let us muster all in pomp,
For here will be the rich infanta, presently,
To make her visit. Peny-boy the heir,
My patron, has got leave for her to play
With all her train, of the old churl, her guardian.
Now is your time to make all court unto her;
That she may first but know, then love the place,
And show it by her frequent visits here:
And afterwards, get her to sojourn with you.
She will be weary of the prodigal, quickly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Brother Picklock,
I shall adore thee, for this parcel of tidings,
It will cry up the credit of our office,
Eternally, and make our staple immortal!

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.l: Look your addresses, then, be fair and fit,
and entertain her, and her creatures, too,
With all the migniardise , and quaint caresses,
You can put on 'em.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Thou seemest, by thy language,
No less a courtier, than a man of law.
I must embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Tut, I am Vertumnus,
On every change, or chance, upon occasion,
A true chameleon, I can colour for't.
I move upon my axle, like a turnpike.
Fit my face to the parties, and become
Straight, one of them.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Sirs, up, into your desks,
And spread the rolls upon the table, so.
Is the examiner set?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Ambler, and buz,
Are both abroad, now.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: We'll sustain their parts.
No matter, let them ply the affairs without,
Fitton puts on the office cloak, and Cymbal the gown. let us alone within, I like that well.
On with the cloak, and you with the staple gown,
And keep your state, stoop only to the infanta;
We'll have a flight at mortgage, statute, band,
And hard, but we'll bring wax unto the retrieve:
Each know his several province, and discharge it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Fitton is brought about. I do admire this nimble engine, Picklock.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Coz,
What did I say?

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Ii.
div.stage: Peniboy. Iv. P. Canter. Pecunia. Statute. Band. Mortgage. Wax. broker. Customers.

sp.l: By your leave, gentlemen, what news? good, good still?
I'your new office? Princess, here's the staple!
This is the governor, kiss him, noble Princess,
For my sake. Thom, how is it honest Thom?
How does thy place, and thou? my creature, Princess?
he tells Pecunia of Thom.this is my creature, give him your hand to kiss,
He was my barber, now he writes clericus!
I bought this place for him, and gave it him.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: He should have spoke of that, sir, and not you:
Two do not do one office well.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
But I am loath to lose my courtesies.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: So are all they, that do them, to vain ends,
and yet you do lose, when you pay yourselves .

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: No more of your sentences, Canter, they are stale,
We come for news, remember where you are.
I pray thee let my Princess hear some news,
Good master Cymbal.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: What news would she hear?
Or of what kind, sir?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Any, any kind.
So it be news, the newest that thou hast,
Some news of state, for a Princess.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: They write, the King of Spain is chosen Pope.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: How? news from Rome.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And emperor too, the thirtieth of February.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: No, but he has resigned,news of the emperor, and Tilly.
And trails a pike now, under Tilly.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: These will beget strange turns in Christendom!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And Spinola is made general of the Jesuits. news of Spinola. The fifth monarchy, uniting the ecclesiastic and secular power. A plot of the house of Austria. More of Spinola.
