sp.speaker: Fit,
sp.p: Sir, all are alike true, and certain.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: All the pretence to the fifth monarchy,
Was held but vain, until the ecclesiastic,
And secular powers, were united, thus,
Both in one person.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'T has been long the aim
Of the house of Austria.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: See but Maximilian,
His letters to the baron of Bouttersheim,
Or Scheiter-huyssen.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No, of Liechtenstein,
Lord Paul, I think.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I have heard of some such thing.
Don Spinola made general of the Jesuits!
A priest!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: O, no, he is dispensed with all,
And the whole society, who do now appear
The only engineers of Christendom.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: They have been thought so long, and rightly too.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Witness the engine, that they have presented him,
To wind himself with, up, into the moon:
And thence make all his discoveries!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And Vittellesco, he that was last general,
Being now turned cook to the society,
Has dressed his excellence, such a dish of eggs —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, powdered. his eggs.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: All the yolk is wild fire,
As he shall need beleaguer no more towns,
But throw his egg in.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: It shall clear consume,
Palace, and place; demolish and bear down,
All strengths before it!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Never be extinguished!
Till all become one ruin!

sp.speaker: F●.
sp.l: And from Florence,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: They write was found in Galileo's study,
A burning glass (Which they have sent him too) Galilaeo's study.
To fire any fleet that's out at sea —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: His strengths will be unresistable, if this hold! the burning glass, by moonshine.
Ha'you no news against him, on the contrary?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 〈…〉 eel. yes, sit, they write here, one Cornelius - 〈◊〉,
Hath made the Hollanders an invisible eel,
To swim the haven at Dunkirk, and sink all
The shipping there.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Why had not you this, Thom?
Because he keeps the pontificial side.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Peny-boy will have him change sides ▪how, change sides, Thom. 'twas never in my thought
To put thee up against ourselves. Come down,
Quickly.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I ventured not my money
Upon those terms: if he may change; why so.
I'll ha' him keep his own side, sure.

sp.speaker: Fit,
sp.l: Why, let him,
'Tis but writing so much over again.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: For that I'll bear the charge: there's two pieces,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Come, do not stick with the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I'll take none sir ▪
And yet he shall ha'the place.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: They shall be 〈…〉,
though he pay for it. up, Thom: and th'office shall take 'em. Keep your side, Thom.
Know your own side, do not forsake your side, Thom.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: They write here one Cornelius - 〈◊〉,
Hath made the Hollanders an invisible eel,
To swim the haven at Dunkirk, and sink all
The shipping there.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I'll show you sir
It is an automa, runs under water,
With a snug nose, and has a nimble tail
Made like an anger, with which tail she wriggles
Betwixt the coasts of a ship, and sinks it straight.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: From a right hand I assure you,
The ecle-boats here, that lie before Queen-hyth,
Came out of holland.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: A most brave device,
To murder their flat bottoms.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I do grant you ▪
Spinola's new project: an army in cork-shoes. but what if Spinola have a new project:
To bring an army over in cork-shoes,
And land them, here, at Harwich? all his horse
Are shod with cork, and fourscore pieces of ordinance,
Mounted upon cork-carriages, with bladders,
In stead of wheels to run the passage over
At a springtide.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As true as the rest ▪

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: He'll never leave his engines: I would hear now
Some curious news.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Magic, or 〈◊〉
Or flying i'the air, I care not what.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They write from Libtzig (Reverence to your 〈◊〉)
The art of drawing farts out of dead bodies,
extraction of farts is by the brotherhood of the rosy cross,
Produced unto perfection, in so sweet
And rich a tincture —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As there is no Princess,
But may perfume her chamber with th'extraction.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: the perpetual motion. and what hast thou, Thom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The perpetual motion ▪
is here found out by an alewife in saint Katherine's,
At the sign of the dancing bears ▪

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What, from her tap?
I'll go see that, or else I'll send old Canter.
He can make that discovery.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Let me have all this news, made up, and sealed ▪

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: The people press upon us, please you, sir,the register offers him a room.
Withdraw with your fair Princess. There's a room
Within, sir, to retire too.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: No, good register,
We'll stand it out here, and observe your office;the office called the house of fame.
What news it issues.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: 'Tis the house of fame, sir,
Where both the curious, and the negligent;
The scrupulous, and careless; wild, and stayed;
The idle, and laborious; all do meet,
To taste the cornu copiae of her rumours,
Which she, the mother of sport ▪ pleaseth to scatter
Among the vulgar: baits, sir, for the people!
And they will bite like fishes.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: Ha'you in your profane shop, any news
O'the saints at Amsterdam?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Yes, how much would you? 1. Cust. ash baptist.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: Lay your money down, read, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The saints do write, they expect a prophet, shortly,
The prophet Baal, to be sent over to them,prophet Baal expected in Helland.
To calculate a time, and half a time,
And the whole time, according to naömetry.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The measuring o'the temple: a cabal
Found out but lately, and set out by Archie,
Or some such head, of whose long coat they have heard,
And being black, desire it.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: Peace be with them! Archie mourned then.

sp.speaker: Reg ▪
sp.l: So there had need, for they are still by the ears
One with another.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.p: Have you no other of that species?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Yes,
But dearer, it will cost you a shilling.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: Verily,
There is a ninepence, I will shed no more.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: Not, to the good o'the saints?

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: I am not sure,
That, man is good.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Read, from Constantinople,
Nine penny'orth.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: They give out here,the great Turk turned christian ▪ the grand signior
Is certainly turned christian, and to clear
The controuersie'twixt the Pope and him,
Which is the Antichrist; he means to visit
The church at Amsterdam, this very summer,
And quit all marks o'the beast.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: Now joyful tidings.
Who brought in this? Which emissary?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Buz.
Your countryman.

sp.speaker: Dop.
sp.l: Now, blessed be the man,
And his whole family, with the nation.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Yes, for Amboyna, and the justice there!
This is a doper, a she Anabaptist!
Seal and deliver her her news, dispatch.

sp.speaker: C. 2.
sp.l: Ha'you any news from the Indies? any miracle
2. Cust. done in Japan, by the Jesuites? or in China?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: a colony ●e cooks sent over to convert the cannibals.no, but we hear of a colony of cooks
To be set ashore o'the coast of America,
For the conversion of the cannibals,
And making them good, eating Christians.
Here comes the colonel that undertakes it.

sp.speaker: C. 2.
sp.p: 3. Cust. by colonel Lickfinger.who? captain Lickfinger?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: News, news my boys!
I am to furnish a great feast today,
And I would have what news the office affords.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We were venting some of you, of your new project,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: Afore 'twas paid for, you were somewhat too hasty.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What Lickfinger! wilt thou convert the cannibals,
With spit and pan divinity?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Sir, for that
I will not urge, but for the fire and zeal
To the true cause; thus I have undertaken:
With two lay-brethren, to myself, no more,
One o'the broach, th'other o'the boiler,
In one six months, and by plain cookery,
No magic to't, but old japnets physic,
The father of the European arts,
To make such sauces for the savages,
And cooks their meats, with those enticing steams,
As it would make our Caniball-christians,
Forbear the mutual eating one another,
Which they do do, more cunningly, than the wild
Anthropophagi; that snatch only strangers,
Like my old patron's dogs, there.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: O, my uncle's!
Is dinner ready, Lickfinger?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: When you please, sir.
I was bespeaking but a parcel of news,
To strew out the long meal withal, but't seems
You are furnished here already.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: What court-news is there? any proclamations,
Or edicts to come forth.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, there is one.
That the King's barber has got, for aid of our trade:
Whereof there is a manifest decay.
to let long hair run to seed ▪ to sow bald pates. a precept for the wearing of long hair,
To run to seed, to sow bald pates withal,
And the preserving fruitful heads, and chins,
To help a mystery, almost antiquated.
Such as are bald and barren beyond hope,
Are to be separated, and set by
For ushers, to old countesses.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: And coachmen.
To mount their boxes, reverently, and drive,
Like lapwings, with a shell upo'their heads.
Thorough the streets. Ha'you no news oh the stage?
They'll ask me about new plays, at dinner time.
And I should be as dumb as a fish.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O! yes.
There is a legacy left to the King's players,Spalato's legacy to the players.
Both for their various shifting of their scene,
And dexterous change o'their persons to all shapes,
And all disguises: by the right reverend
Archbishop of Spalato.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: He is dead,
That played him!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Then, h'has lost his share of the legacy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A second fistula,
Or an excoriation (At the least)
For putting the poor english-play, was writ of him,Gundomar's use of the game at chess, or play so called.
To such a sordid use, as (Is said) he did,
Of cleansing his posteriors.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Since when, he lives condemned to his share, at Brussels.
And there sits filing certain politic hinges,
To hang the states on, h'has heaved off the hooks.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: What must you have for these?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thou shalt pay nothing,
But reckon 'em in i'the bill. There's twenty pieces,
Her grace bestows upon the office, Thom,he gives 20. pieces, to the office. Doubles it.
Write thou that down for news.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: We may well do't,
We have not many such.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: There's twenty more,
If you say so; my Princess is a Princess!
And put that too, under the office seal.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: If it will please your grace to sojourn here,Cymbal takes Pecunia aside, courts and woos her, to the office.
And take my roof for covert, you shall know
The rites belonging to your blood, and birth,
Which few can apprehend: these sordid servants,
Which rather are your keepers, than attendants,
Should not come near your presence. I would have
You waited on by ladies, and your train
Born up by persons of quality, and honour,
Your meat should be served in with curious dances,
And set upon the board, with virgin hands,
Tuned to their voices; not a dish removed,
But to the music, nor a drop of wine,
Mixed, with his water, without harmony,

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: You are a courtier, sir, or somewhat more;
That have this tempting language!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I'm your servant,
Excellent Princess, and would ha'you appear
That, which you are. Come forth state, and wonder,
Of these our times, dazzle the vulgar eyes.
And strike the people blind with admiration.

sp.speaker: P. can.
sp.l: Why, that's the end of wealth! thrust riches outward,
And remain beggars within: contemplate nothing
But the vile sordid things of time, place, money,
And let the noble, and the precious go,
Virtue and honesty; hang 'em; poor thin membranes
Of honour; who respects them? O, the fates!
How hath all just, true reputation fallen,
Fitton hath been courting the waiting-women, this while, and is jeered by them. since money, this base money 'gan to have any!

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.p: Pity, the gentleman is not immortal.

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: As he gives out, the place is, by description.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A very paradise, if you saw all, lady.

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.l: I am the chambermaid, sir, you mistake,
My lady may see all.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Sweet mistress statute, gentle mistress band,
And mother mortgage, do but get her grace
To sojourn here. —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: I thank you gentle wax,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If it were a chattel, I would try my credit.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: So it is, for term of life, we count it so.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: She means, inheritance to him, and his heirs ▪
Or that he could assure a state, of years:
I'll be his statute-staple, statute-merchant,
Or what he please.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: His cousin alderman security,
That he did talk of so, e'en now —

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Who, is
The very broach o'the bench, gem o'the city.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: He and his deputy, but assure his life
For one seven years.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: And see what we'll do for him,
Upon his scarlet motion.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: And old chain,
That draws the city-eares.

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.l: When he says nothing,
But twirls it thus.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Dumb rhetoric, and silent eloquence!
As the fine poet says!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come, they all scorn us,
Do you not see't? the family of scorn!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Do not believe him! gentle master picklock,
They understood you not: the gentlewomen,
They thought you would ha' my lady sojourn, with you,
And you desire but now and then, a visit?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Yes, if she pleased, sir, it would much advance
Unto the office, her continual residence!
(I speak but as a member)

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: 'Tis enough.
I apprehend you. And it shall go hard,
But I'll so work, as somebody shall work her!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Pray you change with our master, but a word about it.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Well, Lickfinger, see that our meat be ready,
Thou hast news enough.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Something of Bethlem Gabor,
And then I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: We hear he has devised
Bethlem Gabor's drum. a drum, to fill all Christendom with the sound:
But that he cannot draw his forces near it,
To march yet, for the violence of the noise.
And therefore he is fain by a design,
To carry 'em in the air, and at some distance,
Till he be married, than they shall appear.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Or never; well, God b'wi'you (Stay, who's here?)
A little of the Duke of Bavier, and then —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He has taken a grey habit,the Duke of Bavier. and is turned
The church's miller, grinds the Catholic grist
With every wind: and Tilly takes the toll.

sp.speaker: Cus. 4.
sp.l: Ha'you any news o'the pageants to send down?
Into the several counties. 4. Cust. the pageants. all the country
Expected from the city most brave speeches ▪
Now, at the coronation.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: It expected
More than it understood: for, they stand mute,
Poor innocent dumb things; they are but wood.
As is the bench and blocks, they were wrought on, yet
If May-day come, and the sun shine, perhaps,
They'll sing like Memnon's statue, and be vocal.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: None very wild, sir,
Some tame there is, out o'the forest of fools,5. Cust. the new park in the forest of fools.
A new park is a making there, to sever
Cuckolds of antler, from the rascals. Such,
Whose wives are dead, and have since cast their heads,
Shall remain cuckolds-pollard.

sp.speaker: Cus.
sp.p: 1. And I. 2. And I. 3. And I. 4. And I. 5. And I.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Sir, I desire to be excused; and, madam:Peny-boy would invite the master of the office
I cannot leave my office, the first day.
My cousin Fitton here, shall wait upon you.
And emissary picklock.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: I cannot spare him yet, but he shall follow you,
When they have ordered the rolls. Shut up th'office,
When you ha'done, till two o'clock .

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. iii.
div.stage: Shunfield. Almanac. Madrigal. Clerkes.

sp.l: By your leave, clerks,
Where shall we dine today? do you know? the jeerers.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Cannot your office tell us, what brave fellows
Do eat together today, in town, and where?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, there's a gentleman, the brave heir, young Peny-boy,
Dines in Apollo.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Come, let's thither then,
I ha' supped in Apollo!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: No,
But with two gentlewomen, called, the graces ▪

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: They were ever three in poetry.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: We may have a jeer, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Yes, you'll drink, doctor.
(If there be any good meat) as much good wine now,
As would lay up a Dutch ambassador.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: If he dine there, he's sure to have good meat,
For, Lickfinger provides the dinner.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Who?
The glory o'the kitchen? that holds cookery,
A trade from Adam? quotes his broths ▪ and salads?
And swears he's not dead yet, but translated
In some immortal crust, the past of almonds?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: The same. He holds no man can be a poet,
That is not a good cook, to know the palates,
And several tastes o'the time. He draws all arts
Out of the kitchen, but the art of poetry,
Which he concludes the same with cookery.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Tut, he maintains more heresies than that.
He'll draw the magisterium from a minced-pie,
And prefer jellies, to your julips, doctor ▪

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I was at an olla podrida of his making,
Was a brave piece of cookery! at a funeral!
But opening the potlid, he made us laugh,
Who had wept all day! and sent us such a tickling
Into our nostrils, as the funeral feast
Had been a wedding-dinner.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Gi' him allowance,
And that but moderate, he will make a Siren
Sing i'the kettle, send in an Arion,
In a brave broth, and of a watery green,
Just the sea-colour, mounted on the back
Of a grown cunger, but, in such a posture,
As all the world would take him for a dolphin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: He's a rare fellow, without question! but
He holds some paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Ay, and pseudodoxes.
Marry, for most, he's orthodox i'the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: You think not o'your time, we'll come too late,
If we go not presently.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Sirs,
You must get o'this news, to store your office,
Who dines and sups i' the town? where, and with whom?
'Twill be beneficial: when you are stored;
And as we like our fare, we shall reward you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Much like D. Humphries,
But, now and then, as th'wholesome proverb says,
'Twill obsonare samem ambulando.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Shut up the office: gentle brother Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Brother, Nathaniel, I ha'the wine for you.
I hope to see us, one day, emissaries.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why not? 'slid, I despair not to be master!

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Iv.
div.stage: Peniboy. Se. broker. Cymbal.

sp.l: How now? I think I was born under Hercules' star!
Nothing but trouble and tumult to oppress me? he is started with Broker's coming back.
Why come you back? where is your charge?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I ha' brought
A gentleman to speak with you?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: To speak with me?
You know 'tis death for me to speak with any man.
What is he? set me a chair.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: He's the master
Of the great office.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: The staple of news,
A mighty thing, they talk six thousand a year.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: Well bring your six in. Where ha' you left Pecunia?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Sir, in Apollo, they are scarce set.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: He must pardon me,
I cannot rise, a diseased man.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: By no means, sir,
Respect your health, and ease.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: It is no pride in me!
But pain, pain; what's your errand, sir, to me? he sends broker back.
Broker, return to your charge, be argus-eyed,
Awake, to the affair you have in hand,
Serve in Apollo, but take heed of Bacchus.
Go on, sir.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: I am come to speak with you.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: 'Tis pain for me to speak, a very death,
But I will hear you!

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Sir, you have a lady,
That sojourns with you.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Ha? he pretends infirmity. I am somewhat short
In my sense too —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: On that side,
Very imperfect, on —

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Whom I would draw
Oftener to a poor office, I am master of —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: My hearing is very dead, you must speak quicker.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Or, if it please you, sir, to let her sojourn
In part with me; I have a moiety
We will divide, half of the profits.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Ha?
I hear you better now, how come they in?
Is it a certain business, or a casual?
For I am loath to seek out doubtful courses,
Run any hazardous paths, I love straight ways,
A just, and upright man! now all trade totters.
The trade of money, is fallen, two i'the hundred.
That was a certain trade, while th' age was thrifty,
And men good husbands, looked unto their stocks,
Had their minds bounded; now the public riot
Prostitutes all, scatters away in coaches,
In footmen's coats, and waiting women's gowns,
They must have velvet haunches (With a pox)
now taken up, and yet not pay the use;
he talks vehemently and aloud. bate of the use? I am mad with this times manners.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: You said e'en now, it was death for you to speak.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Ay, but an anger, a just anger, (As this is)
Puts life in man. Who can endure to see
The fury of men's gullets, and their groins?
is moved more and more. what fires, what cooks, what kitchens might be spared?
What stews, ponds, parks, coupes, garners, magazines?
What velvets, tissues, scarves, embroideries?
And laces they might lack? They covet things —
Superfluous still; when it were much more honour
They could want necessary! What need hath nature
Of silver dishes? or gold chamberpots?
Of perfumed napkins? or a numerous family,
To see her eat? Poor, and wise she, requires
Meat only; hunger is not ambitious:
Say, that you were the emperor of pleasures,
The great dictator of fashions, for all Europe,
And had the pomp of all the courts, and kingdoms,
Laid forth unto the show? to make yourself
Gazed, and admired at? You must go to bed,
And take your natural rest: then, all this vanisheth.
Your bravery was but shown; 'twas not possessed:
While it did boast itself, it was then perishing.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: All that excess
Appeared as little yours, as the spectators.
It scarce fills up the expectation
Of a few hours, that entertains men's lives.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: He has the monopoly of sole-speaking.
he is angry. why, good sir? you talk all.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Why should I not?
Is it not under mine own roof? my feeling?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: But I came here to talk with you.

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.l: Why, an' i will not
Talk with you, sir? you are answered, who sent for you?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: bids him get out of his house. nobody sent for me —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: But you came, why then
Go, as you came, here's no man holds you, there,
There lies your way, you see the door.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: 'Tis my civility, when I do not relish
The party, or his business. Pray you be gone, sir.
I'll ha' no venture in your ship, the office
Your bark of six, if 'twere sixteen, good, sir,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: I think I am sir, truly.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: Cymbal rails at him. He jeers him. a rascal, and a money-bawd.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: My surnames:

sp.speaker: P. S.
sp.l: You will overflow —
And spill all.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Caterpillar, moth,
Horseleech, and dung-worm —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Still you lose your labour.
I am a broken vessel, all runs out:
'A shrunk old dry-fat. Fare you well, good six.

div.head: The third intermean after the third act.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: A notable tough rascal! this old Peny-boy! right city-bred!

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: In Silver-street, the region of money, a good seat for a usurer.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: He has rich ingredients in him, I warrant you, if they were extracted, a true receipt to make an alderman, an' he were well wrought upon, according to art.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: I would fain see an alderman in chimia! that is a treatise of aldermanity truly written.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: To show how much it differs from urbanity.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Ay, or humanity. Either would appear in this Peny-boy, an' he were rightly distilled. But how like you the news? you are gone from that.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: O, they are monstrous! scurvy! and stale! and too exotic! ill cooked! and ill dished!

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: They were as good, yet, as butter could make them!

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: In a word, they were beastly buttered! he shall never come of my bread more, nor my in mouth, if I can help it. I have had better news from the bakehouse, by ten thousand parts, in a morning: or the conduits in Westminster! all the news of Tutle-street, and both the alm'ries! the two sanctuaries ▪ long, and round wool-staple! with Kings-street, and Chanon-row to boot!

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Ay, my gossip Tatle knew what fine slips grew in Gardiners-lane; who kissed the butcher's wife with the cowsbreath; what matches were made in the bowling-alley, and what bets won and lost; how much grist went to the mill and what besides: who conjured in Tutle-fields, and how many? when they never came there. And which boy road upon doctor lamb, in the likeness of a roaring lion, that run away with him in his teeth, and has not devoured him yet.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: Why, I had it from my maid Joan Hearsay: and she had it from a limb o'the school, she says, a little limb of nine year old; who told her, the master left out his coniuring book one day, and he found it, and so the fable came about. But whether it were true, or no, we gossips are bound to believe it, an't be once out, and a foot: how should we entertain the time else, or find ourselves in fashionable discourse, for all companies, if we do not credit all, and make more of it, in the reporting?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
For my part, I believe it: and there were no wiser than I, I would have ne'er a cunning schoolmaster in England. I mean a cunning-man, a schoolmaster; that is a conjurer, or a poet, or that had any acquaintance with a poet. They make all their scholars playboys! Is't not a fine sight, to see all our children made interluders? Do we pay our money for this? we send them to learn their
grammar, and their Terence, and they learn their playbooks? well, they talk, we shall have no more parliaments (God bless us) but an'wee have, I hope, Zeal-of-the-land buzy, and my gossip, rabbi Trouble-truth will start up, and see we shall have painful good ministers to keep school, and catechise our youth, and not teach 'em to speak plays, and act fables of false news, in this manner, to the supervexation of town and country, with a wanion.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. i.
div.stage: Peny-boy. Iv. Fitton. Shunfield. Almanac. Madrigal. Canter. Picklock.

sp.l: Come, gentlemen, let's breathe from healths a while.
This Lickfinger has made us a good dinner,
For our Pecunia: what shall's do with ourselves,
While the women water? and the fiddlers eat?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: We first begin with ourselves, and then at you,

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: We jeer all kind of persons
We meet withal, of any rank or quality,
And if we cannot jeer them, we jeer ourselves.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: A pretty sweet society! and a grateful!

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Have at you, than lawyer.
They say, there was one of your coat in bedlam, lately,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I wonder all his clients were not there.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Except, sir, one
Like you, and he made verses.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Madrigal,
A jeer.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: But what did you do, lawyer?
When you made love to mistress Band, at dinner.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why? of an advocate, he grew the client.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: And showed the law of nature
Was there above the common-law.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Quit, quit,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Call you this jeering? I can play at this,
'Tis like a ball at tennis.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Very like,
But we were not well in.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed, sir.
When we do speak at volley, all the ill
We can one of another.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: As this morning,
(I would you had heard us) of the rogue your uncle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: We called him a coat-card
O'the last order.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Some readings have it so, my manuscript
Doth speak it, varlet.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: And yourself a fool
O'the first rank, and one shall have the leading
O'the right-hand file, under this brave commander.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Sir, I say this is
A very wholesome exercise, and comely.
Like lepers, showing one another their scabs.
Or flies feeding on ulcers.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What news gentlemen?
Have you any news for after dinner? methinks
We should not spend our time unprofitably.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: They never lie, sir, between meals, 'gainst supper
You may have a bale or two brought in.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: This canter,
Is an old envious knave!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I ha' marked him all this meal, he has done nothing
But mock, with scurvy faces, all we said.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: A supercilious rogue! he looks as if
He were the Patrico —

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Or archpriest o'canters,

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: He's some primate metropolitan rascal,
Our shot-clog makes so much of him.

sp.speaker: Alm
sp.l: The law,
And he does govern him

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: We say, we wonder not, your man of law,
Should be so gracious wi'you; but how it comes,
This rogue, this canter!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A fellow
That speaks no language —

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: But what gingling Gipsies,
And pedlar's trade in —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And no honest christian
Can understand —

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Why? by that argument,
You all are canters, you, and you, and you,he speaks to all the jeerers.
All the whole world are canters, I will prove it
In your professions.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I would fain hear this,
But stay, my Princess comes, provide the while,
I'll call for't anon. How fares your grace?

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. Ii.
div.stage: Lickfinger. Pecunia. Statute-band. Waxe. to them.

sp.p: I hope the fare was good.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Yes, Lickfinger,
Lickfinger is challenged by Madrigal of an argument. and we shall thank you for't and reward you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Nay, I'll not lose my argument, Lickfinger;
Before these gentlemen, I affirm,
The perfect, and true strain of poetry,
Is rather to be given the quick cellar,
Than the fat kitchen.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Heretic, I see
Thou art for the vain oracle of the bottle.
The hogshead, Trismegistus, is thy Pegasus.
Thence flows thy muse's spring, from that hard hoof:
Seduced poet, I do say to thee,
A boiler, range, and dresser were the fountains,
Of all the knowledge in the universe.
And they are the kitchens, where the master-cook —
(Thou dost not know the man, nor canst thou know him,
Till thou hast served some years in that deep school,
That's both the nurse and mother of the arts,
And hearest him read, interpret, and demonstrate!)
A master-cook! Why, he's the man of men,
For a professor! he designes, he draws,
He paints, he carves, he builds, he fortifies,
Makes citadels of curious fowl and fish,
Some he dry-dishes, some motes round with broths.
Mounts marrowbones, cuts fifty angled custards,
Rears bulwark pies, and for his outerworks
He raiseth ramparts of immortal crust;
And teacheth all the tactics, at one dinner:
What ranks, what files, to put his dishes in;
The whole art military. Then he knows,
The influence of the stars upon his meats,
And all their seasons, tempers, qualities,
And so to fit his relishes, and sauces,
He has nature in a pot,'bove all the chemists,
Or airy brothers of the Rosie-crosse.
He is an architect, an engineer,
A soldier, a physician, a philosopher,
A general mathematician.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: And that you may not doubt him, for a poet —

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: This fury shows, if there were nothing else!
And 'tis divine! I shall for ever hereafter,
Admire the wisdom of a cook!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: O, how my Princess draws me, with her looks,Peny-boy is courting his Princess all the while.
And hales me in, as eddies draw in boats,
Or strong Charybdis ships, that sail too near
The shelves of love! The tides of your two eyes!
Wind of your breath, are such as suck in all,
That do approach you!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Yourself, who drink my blood up with your beams;
As doth the sun, the sea! Pecunia shines
More in the world than he: and makes it spring
Where'er she favours! Please her but to show
Her melting wrists, or bare her ivory hands,
She catches still! her smiles they are love's fetters!
Her breasts his apples! her teats strawberries!
Where Cupid (Were he present now) would cry
Fare well my mother's milk, here's sweeter nectar!
Help me to praise Pecunia, gentlemen:
She's your Princess, lend your wits,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A lady,
The graces taught to move!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: The flowers did nurse! they all begin the encomium of Pecunia.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Whose lips are the instructions of all lovers!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Her eyes their lights, and rivals to the stars!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: A voice, as if that harmony still spoke!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And polished skin, whiter than Venus' foot!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Young Hebe's neck, or Juno's arms!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: A hair,
Large as the morning's, and her breath as sweet,
As meadows after rain, and but new mown!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Leda might yield unto her, for a face!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Kiss, kiss 'em, Princess. she kisseth them.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: The pearl doth strive in whiteness, with her neck,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: But loseth by it: here the snow thaws snow;
One frost resolves another!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, she has
A front too slippery to be looked upon!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And glances that beguile the seers eyes!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Kiss, kiss again, what says my man of war? again.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: I say, she's more, than fame can promise of her.
A theme, that's overcome with her own matter!
Praise is struck blind, and deaf, and dumb with her!
She doth astonish commendation!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Well pumped i'faith old sailor: kiss him too:
Though he be a slug. What says my poet-sucker! she kisseth captain Shunfield.
He's chewing his muse's cud, I do see by him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I have almost done, I want but e'en to finish.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: That's the ill luck of all his works still.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: To begin many works, but finish none;

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: How does he do his mistress work?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I cannot think he finisheth that.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Let's hear ▪

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: It is a Madrigal, I affect that kind
Of poem, much.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: And thence you ha' the name.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: It is his rose. He can make nothing else

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: I made it to the tune the fiddlers played,
That we all liked so well.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: The sun is father of all metals, you know,
Silver, and gold.

sp.speaker: Madrigal.
sp.l: As bright as is the sun her sire,
Or earth her mother, in her best attire,
Or mint, the midwife, with her sire,
Comes forth her grace!
The splendour of the wealthiest mines!
The stamp, and strength of all imperial lines,
Both majesty and beauty shines,
In her sweet face!
Look how a torch, of taper light,
Or of that torch's flame, a beacon bright;

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: That mint the midwife does well.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now there, I want a line to finish, sir.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Or of that beacons fire, moonlight:

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: 'Tis good.
And then I have a saraband —
She makes good cheer, she keeps full boards,
She holds a fair of knights, and lords,
A mercat of all offices,
And shops of honour, more or less.
According to Pecunia's grace,
The bride hath beauty, blood, and place,
The bridegroom virtue, valour, wit,
And wisdom, as he stands for it.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Call in the fiddlers. Nick, the boy shall sing it,
he urgeth her to kiss them all. sweet Princess, kiss him, kiss 'em all, dear madam,
And at the close, vouchsafe to call them cousins.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Sweet cousin Madrigal, and cousin Fitton,
My cousin Shunfield, and my learned cousin.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: Almanac, though they call him almanac.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Why, here's the prodigal prostitutes his mistress!

sp.speaker: P·iu.
sp.l: And picklock, he must be a kinsman too.
My man of law will teach us all to win,
And keep our own. Old founder.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Nothing, I sir?
I am a wretch, a beggar. She the fortunate.
Can want no kindred, we, the poor know none.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Nor none shall know, by my consent.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Nor mine,

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Look, look,the boy sings the song. how all their eyes
Dance i'their heads (Observe) scattered with lust!
At sight of their brave idol! how they are tickled,
With a light air! the bawdy saraband!
They are a kind of dancing engines all!
And set, by nature, thus, to run alone
To every sound! All things within, without them,
Move, but their brain, and that stands still! mere monsters
Here, in a chamber, of most subtle feet!
And make their legs in tune, passing the streets!
These are the gallant spirits o'the age!
The miracles o'the time! that can cry up
And down men's wits! and set what rate on things
Their half-brained fancies please! Now pox upon 'em.
See how solicitously he learns the jig,
As if it were a mystery of his faith!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, he's a dainty poet!
When he sets to't!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And a dainty scholar! they are all struck with admiration.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: No, no great scholar, he writes like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Pox o'your distinction!
As if a scholar were no gentleman.
With these, to write like a gentleman, will in time
Become, all one, as to write like an ass,
These gentlemen? these rascals! I am sick
Of indignation at 'em.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: I am telling mistress band, and mistress statute,
What a brave gentleman you are, and wax, here!
How much 'twere better, that my lady's grace,
Would here take up sir, and keep house with you.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: Ay, if we knew her grace had the least liking.

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.p: We must obey her graces will, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I thank you, gentlewomen, ply 'em, Lickfinger.
Give mother mortgage, there —

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Her dose of sack.
I have it for her, and her distance of hum.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Indeed therein, I must confess, dear cousin,the gallants are all about Pecunia.
I am a most unfortunate Princess.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And
You still will be so, when your grace may help it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Who'd lie in a room, with a close-stool, and garlic?
And kennel with his dogs? that had a prince
Like this young Peny-boy, to sojourn with?

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: He'll let you ha' your liberty —

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Go forth,
Whither you please, and to what company —

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: Scatter yourself amongst us —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Hope of Parnassus!
Thy ivy shall not wither, nor thy bays,
Thou shalt be had into her grace's cellar,
And there know sack, and claret, all December,
Thy vein is rich, and we must cherish it.
Poets and bees swarm now adays, but yet
There are not those good taverns, for the one sort,
As there are flowery fields to feed the other.
Though bees be pleased with dew, ask little wax
That brings the honey to her lady's hive:
The poet must have wine. And he shall have it.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene. Iv.
div.stage: Peniboy. Se. Peny-boy. Iv. Lickfinger. Etc.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: I am abused, where is my knave? my broker?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Your broker is laid out upon a bench, yonder,
Sack hath seized on him, in the shape of sleep.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: He hath been dead to us almost this hour.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: Why sigh you sir? 'cause he's at rest?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Will you take a cup
he strikes the sack out of his hand. and try if you can sleep?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: No, cogging Jack,
Thou and thy cups too, perish.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: Or rather an elegy, for the sack is gone.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Why do you this, sir? spill the wine, and rave?
For broker's sleeping?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: What through sleep, and sack,
My trust is wronged: but I am still awake,
he would have Pecunia home. But she refuseth. And her train. to wait upon your grace, please you to quit
This strange lewd company, they are not for you.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: No guardian, I do like them very well.

sp.speaker: P. se
sp.l: Your grace's pleasure be observed, but you
Statute, and band, and wax, will go with me.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: We will stay, and wait here
Upon her grace, and this your noble kinsman.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: Noble? how noble! who hath made him noble?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Why, my most noble money hath, or shall ▪
My Princess, here. She that had you but kept,
And treated kindly, would have made you noble,
And wise, too: nay, perhaps have done that for you,
An act of parliament could not, made you honest.
The truth is, uncle, that her grace dislikes
Her entertainment: specially her lodging.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Nay, say her jail. Never unfortunate Princess,
Was used so by a jailor. Ask my women,
Band, you can tell, and statute, how he has used me,
Kept me close prisoner, under twenty bolts —

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: And forty padlocks —

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: All malicious engines
A wicked smith could forge out of his iron:
As locks, and keys, shackles, and manacles,
To torture a great lady.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: H'has abused
Your grace's body.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: No, he would ha' done,
That lay not in his power: he had the use
Of our bodies, band, and wax, and sometimes statutes:
But once he would ha' smothered me in a chest,
And strangled me in leather, but that you
Came to my rescue, then, and gave me air.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: For which he crammed us up in a close box,
All three together, where we saw no sun
In one six months.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: H'has left my fellow wax out, i'the cold,

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Till she was stiff, as any frost, and crumbled
Away to dust, and almost lost her form.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Women jeerers!
Have you learned too, the subtle faculty?
Come, I'll show you the way home, if drink,
Or, too full diet have disguised you.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Troth,
We have not any mind, sir, of return —

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: To be bound back to back. —

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: And have our legs
Turned in, or writhed about —

sp.speaker: Wax.
sp.l: Or else displayed —

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.l: Be lodged with dust and fleas, as we were wont —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Why? you whores,
My bawds, my instruments, what should I call you,
Man may think base enough for you?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Hear you, uncle.
I must not hear this of my Princess servants,
And in Apollo, in Pecunia's room,
Go, get you down the stairs: home, to your kennel,
As swiftly as you can. Consult your dogs,
The lares of your family; or believe it,
The fury of a footman, and a drawer
Hangs over you.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Cudgel, and pot do threaten
A kind of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: The pumpthey all threaten,
Is not far off; if't were, the sink is near:
Or a good Jordan.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: You have now no money,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: I am cheated, robbed
Jeered by confederacy.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No, you are kicked
And used kindly, as you should be.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Spurned,and spurn him.
from all commerce of men, who are a cur.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p:
Kick him, out ▪
He exclaims. a stinking dog, in a doublet, with foul linen.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Well, remember,
I am cozened by my cousin, and his whore!
Bane o'these meetings in Apollo!

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Go, sir,
one of his dogs. you will be tossed like block, in a blanket else.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Saucy Jack away,
Pecunia is a whore.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Play him down, fiddlers,
And drown his noise. Who's this!

div.head: Act. iv. scene. Iv.
div.stage: Pyed-mantle. to them.

sp.p: Pied-mantle brings the lady Pecunia her pedigree.by your leave, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Her grace's herald,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: O, thou saidst thou'dst sprone us all so!

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Sir, here is one will prove himself so, straight,
So shall the rest, in time.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: My pedigree?
I tell you, friend, he must be a good scholar,
Can my descent. I am of princely race,
And as good blood, as any is i'the mines,
Runs through my veins. I am, every limb, a Princess!
Duchess of mines, was my great grandmother.
And by the father's side, I come from sol.
My grandfather was Duke of or, and matched
In the blood-royal of Ophyr.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: I know it, if I hear the blazon.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: He bears
In a field azure, a sun proper, beamy,
Twelve of the second.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: That is our coat too, as we come from Or.
What line's this?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: The rich mines of Potosi.
The Spanish mines i'the West-indies.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: The mines of Hungary, this of Barbary.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: I ha' welsh-blood in me too, blaze, sir, that coat.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: She bears (An't please you) argent, three leeks vert
In Canton or, and tasselled of the first.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: Is not this canting? do you understand him?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Not I, but it sounds well, and the whole thing
Is rarely painted, I will have such a scroll,
whate'er it cost me.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.l: Well, at better leisure,
We'll take a view of it, and so reward you.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Kiss him, sweet Princess, and style him a cousin. she kisseth.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: I will, if you will have it. Cousin Pied-mantle.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I love all men of virtue, from my Princess,
Unto my beggar, here, old Canter, on,
On to thy proof, whom prove you the next canter?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: The doctor here, I will proceed with the learned.
When he discourseth of dissection,
Or any point of anatomy: that he tells you,
Of vena cava, and of vena porta,
The meseraicks, and the mesenterium.
What does he else but cant? Or if he run
To his judicial astrology,
And troll the trine, the quartile and the sextile,
Platic aspect, and partile, with his hyleg
Or Alchochoden, cusps, and horoscope.
Does not he cant? Who here does understand him?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Or when my muster-master
Talks of his tactics, and his ranks, and files;
His bringers up, his leaders on, and cries,
Faces about to the right hand, the left,
Now, as you were: then tells you of redoubts,
Of cats, and cortines. Doth not he cant?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: My egg-chinned laureate, here, when he comes forth
With dimeters, and trimeters, tetrameters,
Pentameters, hexameters, catalecticks,
His hyper, and his brachy-catalecticks,
His pyrrhichs, epitrites, and choriambicks.
What is all this, but canting?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Nay, I do cherish virtue, though in rags.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Now he treats of you,
Stand forth to him, fair.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: With all your fly-blown projects,
And looks out of the politics, your shut-faces,
And reserved questions, and answers that you game with, as
Is't a clear business? will it manage well?
My name must not be used else. Here, 'twill dash.
Your business has received a taint, give off,
I may not prostitute myself. Tut, tut,
That little dust I can blow off, at pleasure.
Here's no such mountain, yet, i'the whole work!
But a light purse may level. I will tide
This affair for you; give it freight, and passage.
And such mint-phrase, as 'tis the worst of canting,
By how much it affects the sense, it has not.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: This is some other than he seems!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: But he is, sir,
And shall be still, and so shall you be too:
We'll all be canters. Now, I think of it,
A noble whimsy's come into my brain!
Canters-colledge, begun to be erected. I'll build a college, ay, and my Pecunia,
And call it canter's college, sounds it well?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And here stands my father rector,
And you professors, you shall all profess
Something, and live there, with her grace and me,
Your founders: I'll endow't with lands, and means,
And Lickfinger shall be my master-cook.
What? is he gone?

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: And read Apicius de reculinaria
To your brave doxy, and you!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: You, cousin Fitton,
Shall (As a courtier) read the politics;
Doctor almanac, he shall read astrology,
Shunfield shall read the military arts.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: that's Madrigal.as carving, and assaulting the cold custard.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And Horace here, the art of poetry.
His lyrics, and his madrigals, fine songs,
Which we will have at dinner, steeped in claret,
And against supper, soused in sack.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.l: In troth
A divine whimsy!

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: And a worthy work,
Fit for a chronicle!

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And Pied-mantle, shall give us all our arms,
But picklock, what wouldst thou be? Thou canst cant too.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: In all the languages in Westminster-hall,
Fleas, bench, or chancery. Fee-farm, fee-tail,
Tenant in dower, at will, for term of life,
By copy of court roll, knight's service, homage,
Fealty, escuage, soccage, or frank almoigne,
Grand sergeanty, or burgage.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Thou appearest,
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 a canter. Thou shalt read
All Littleton's tenures to me, and indeed
All my conveyances.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: And make 'em too, sir?
Keep all your courts, be steward o'your lands,
Let all your leases, keep your evidences,
But first, I must procure, and pass your mortmain
You must have licence from above, sir.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Fear not,
Pecunia's friends shall do it.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: But I shall stop it.
Your worship's loving, and obedient father,
Your painful steward, and lost officer!
here his father discovers himself. who have done this, to try how you would use
Pecunia, when you had her: which since I see,
I will take home the lady, to my charge,
And these her servants, and leave you my cloak,
To travel in to beggar's bush! A seat,
is built already, furnished too, worth twenty
Of your imagined structures, canter's college.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I knew he was no rogue!

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Thou, prodigal,
Was I so careful for thee, to procure,
And plot with my learned counsel, master picklock,
This noble match for thee, and dost thou prostitute,
Scatter thy mistress favours, throw away
Her bounties, as they were red-burning coals,
Too hot for thee to handle, on such rascals?
Who are the scum, and excrements of men?
If thou hadst sought out good, and virtuous persons
Of these professions: I'had loved thee, and them.
For these shall never have that plea 'gainst me,
Or colour of advantage, that I hate
Their callings, but their manners, and their vices.
A worthy courtier, is the ornament
Of a King's palace, his great master's honour.
This is a moth, a rascal, a court-rat,
That gnaws the commonwealth with broking suits,
And eating grievances! So, a true soldier,
He is his country's strength, his sovereign's safety,
And to secure his peace, he makes himself.
The heir of danger, nay the subject of it,
And runs those virtuous hazards, that this scarecrow
Cannot endure to hear of.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: With you I dare be! Here is Pied-mantle,
'Cause he's an ass, do not I love a herald?
Who is the pure preserver of descents,
The keeper fair of all nobility,
Without which all would run into confusion?
Were he a learned herald, I would tell him
He can give arms, and marks, he cannot honour,
No more than money can make noble: it may
Give place, and rank, but it can give no virtue.
And he would thank me, for this truth. This dog-leech,
You style him doctor, 'cause he can compile
An almanac; perhaps erect a scheme
For my great madam monkey: when 't has taken
A glister, and bewrayed the Ephemerides.
Do I despise a learned physician?
In calling him a quacksalver? or blast
The everliving garland, always green
Of a good poet? when I say his wreath
Is pieced and patched of dirty withered flowers?
Away, I am impatient of these ulcers,
(That I not call you worse) there is no sore,
or plague but you to infect the times. I abhor
Your very scent. Come, lady, since my prodigal
Knew not to entertain you to your worth,
I'll see if I have learned, how to receive you,
he points him to his patched cloak thrown off. with more respect to you, and your fair train here.
Farewell my beggar in velvet, for today,
Tomorrow you may put on that grave robe,
And enter your great work of canter's college,
Your work and worthy of a chronicle,

div.head: The fourth intermean after the fourth act.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: Why? This was the worst of all! the catastrophe!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: The matter began to be good, but now: and he has spoiled it all, with his beggar there!

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: A beggarly Jack it is, I warrant him, and a kin to the poet.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: Like enough, for he had the chiefest part in his play, if you mark it.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Absurdity on him, for a huge overgrown playmaker! why should he make him live again, when they, and we all thought him dead? If he had left him to his rags, there had been an end of him.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: Ay, but set a beggar on horseback, he'll never lin till he be a gallop.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: The young heir grew a fine gentleman, in this last act!

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: So he did, gossip: and kept the best company.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: And showed her to 'em all! was not jealous!

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: But very communicative, and liberal, and began to be magnificent, if the churl his father would have let him alone.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: It was spitefully done of the poet, to make the chuff take him off in his height, when he was going to do all his brave deeds!

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Plant his professors, and water his lectures.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: With wine, gossips, as he meant to do, and then to defraud his purposes?

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Kill the hopes of so many towardly young spirits?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And the courtiers! I protest, I was in love with master Fitton. He did wear all he had, from the hatband, to the shoe-tie, so politically, and would stoop, and leer?

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: And lie so, in wait for a piece of wit, like a mousetrap?

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Indeed gossip, so would the little doctor, all his behaviour was mere glister! On my conscience, he would make any party's physic i' the world work, with his discourse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I wonder they would suffer it, a foolish old fornicating father, to ravish away his son's mistress.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And all her women, at once, as he did!

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: I would ha' flyen in his gypsies face i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: It was a plain piece of political incest, and worthy to be brought afore the high commission of wit. Suppose we were to censure him, you are the youngest voice, gossip Tatle, begin.

sp.speaker: Tatle.
sp.p: Marry, I would ha' the old coney-catcher cozened of all he has, i'the young heir's defence, by his learned counsel, Mr. picklock!

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I would rather the courtier had found out some trick to beg him, from his estate!

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Or the captain had courage enough to beat him.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Or the fine madrigal-man, in rhyme, to have run him out of the country, like an Irish rat.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: No, I would have master Pied-mantle, her grace's herald, to pluck down his hatchments, reverse his coat-armour, and nullify him for no gentleman.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Nay, then let master doctor dissect him, have him opened, and his tripes translated to Lickfinger, to make a probation dish of.

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: Faith I would have him flat disinherited, by a decree of court, bound to make restitution of the lady Pecunia, and the use of her body to his son.

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: And her train, to the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And both the poet, and himself, to ask them all forgiveness!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.l: In two large sheets of paper —

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Or to stand in a skin of parchment, (Which the court please)

sp.speaker: Mirth.
sp.p: And dedicated to the sustaining of the staple!

sp.speaker: Exp.
sp.p: Which their poet hath let fall, most abruptly?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: You say wittily, gossip, and therefore let a protest go out against him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A mournival of protests; or a gleek at least!

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.p: Subsigned. Tatle, stay, they come again.

div.head: Act. v. scene. i.
div.stage: Peny-boy. Iv. to him Tho. Barber. after, Picklocke.

sp.l: he comes out in the patched cloak his father left him. nay, they are fit, as they had been made for me,
And I am now a thing, worth looking at!
The same, I said I would be in the morning.
No rogue, at a comitia of the canters,
Did ever there become his parents robes
Better, than I do these: great fool! and beggar!
Why do not all that are of those societies,
Come forth, and gratulate me one of theirs?
Methinks , I should be, on every side, saluted,
Dauphin of beggars! Prince of prodigals!
That have so fallen under the ears, and eyes,
And tongues of all, the fable o'the time,
Matter of scorn, and mark of reprehension!
I now begin to see my vanity,
Shine in this glass, reflected by the foil!
Where is my fashioner? my featherman?
My linener? Perfumer? Barber? all?
That tail of riot, followed me this morning?
Not one! but a dark solitude about me,
Worthy my cloak, and patches; as I had
The epidemical disease upon me:
And I'll sit down with it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: My master! Maker!
How do you? Why do you sit thus o'the ground, sir?
Hear you the news?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: No, nor I care to hear none.
Would I could here sit still, and slip away
The other one and twenty, to have this
Forgotten, and the day razed out, expunged,
In every Ephemerides, or almanac.
Or if it must be in, that time and nature
Have decreed; still, let it be a day
Of tickling prodigals, about the gills;
Deluding gaping heirs, losing their loves,
And their discretions; falling from the favours
Of their best friends, and parents; their own hopes;
and entering the society of canters.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A doleful day it is, and dismal times
Are come upon us: I am clear undone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Our staple is all to pieces, quite dissolved!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Shivered, as in an earthquake! heard you not
The crack and ruins? we are all blown up!
Soon as they heard th' infanta was got from them,
Whom they had so devoured i'their hopes,
To be their patroness, and sojourn with 'em;
Our emissaries, register, examiner,
Flew into vapour: our grave governor
Into a subtler air; and is returned
(As we do hear) grand-captain of the jeerers.
Ay, and my fellow melted into butter,
And spoiled our ink, and so the office vanished.
The last hum that it made, was, that your father,
And picklock are fallen out, the man of law. he starts up at this.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: How? this awakes me from my lethargy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And a great suit, is like to be between 'em,
Picklock denies the feoffment, and the trust,
(Your father says) he made of the whole estate,
Unto him, as respecting his mortality,
When he first laid this late device, to try you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
Here comes the worshipful —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: What? my velvet-hair,picklock enters.
Turned beggar in mind, as robes?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: You see what case,
Your, and my father's plots have brought me to.

sp.speaker: P. c.
sp.l: Your fathers, you may say, indeed, not mine.
He's a hard hearted gentleman! I am sorry
To see his rigid resolution!
That any man should so put off affection,
And humane nature, to destroy his own!
And triumph in a victory so cruel!
He's fallen out with me, for being yours,
And calls me knave, and traitors to his trust,
Says he will have me thrown over the bar —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: O, good heaven knows
My conscience, and the silly latitude of it!
A narrow minded man! my thoughts do dwell
All in a lane, or line indeed; no turning,
Nor scarce obliquity in them. I still look
Right forward to th'intent, and scope of that
Which he would go from now.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Sir, I had somewhat, will keep you still lord
Of all the estate, (If I be honest) as
I hope I shall. My tender scrupulous breast
will not permit me see the heir defrauded,
And like an alien, thrust out of the blood,
The laws forbid that I should give consent,
To such a civil slaughter of a son.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: Where is the deed? hast thou it with thee?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: No,
It is a thing of greater consequence,
Then to be born about in a black box,
Like a Low-country vorloffe, or welsh-brief.
It is at Lickfinger's, under lock and key.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: I have bid him bring it,
That you might see it.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: No more than a gardiner's ass, what roots he carries,

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I was a sending my father, like an ass,
A penitent epistle, but I am glad
I did not, now.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Hang him, an austere grape,
That has no juice, but what is verjuice in him.

sp.speaker: P●c..
sp.l: Show me a defiance!
Peny-boy runs out to fetch his letter. if I can now commit father, and son,
And make my profits out of both. Commence
A suit with the old man, for his whole state,
And go to law with the son's credit, undo
Both, both with their own money, it were a piece
Worthy my nightcap, and the gown I wear,
A picklocks name in law. Where are you sir?
What do you do so long?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: I cannot find
Where I have laid it, but I have laid it safe.

sp.speaker: Pic
sp.l: No matter, sir, trust you unto my trust,
'Tis that that shall secure you, an absolute deed!
And I confess, it was in trust, for you,
Lest any thing might have happened mortal to him:
But there must be a gratitude thought on,
And aid, sir, for the charges of the suit,
Which will be great, 'gainst such a mighty man,
As is our father, and a man possessed
Of so much land, Pecunia and her friends.
I am not able to wage law with him,
Yet must maintain the thing, as mine own right,
Still for your good, and therefore must be bold
To use your credit for moneys.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: What thou wilt,
So we be safe, and the trust bear it.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Fear not,
'Tis he must pay arrearages in the end.
We'll milk him, and Pecunia, draw their cream down,
Before he get the deed into his hands.
My name is picklock, but he'll find me a padlock.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Peny-boy. Can. Peny-boy. Iv. Picklock. Tho. Barbar.

sp.l: How now? conferring wi' your learned counsel,
Upo'the cheat? Are you o'the plot to cozen me?

sp.speaker: P. ●●.
sp.l: Your counsel knows there, mr.picklock,
Will you restore the trust yet?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Sir, take patience.
And memory unto you, and bethink you,
What trust? where dost appear? I have your deed,
Doth your deed specify any trust? Is't not
A perfect act? and absolute in law?
Sealed and delivered before witnesses?
The day and date, emergent.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: But what conference?
What oaths, and vows preceded?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: I will tell you, sir,
Since I am urged of those, as I remember,
You told me you had got a growen estate,
By griping means, sinisterly.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: And were
E'en weary of it; if the parties lived,
From whom you had wrested it —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: You could be glad,
To part with all, for satisfaction:
But since they had yielded to humanity,
And that just heaven had sent you, for a punishment
(You did acknowledge it) this riotous heir,
That would bring all to beggary in the end,
And daily sowed consumption, where he went —

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: You'old cozen both, then? your confederate, too?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: After a long, mature deliberation,
You could not think, where, better, how to place it —

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: What you please i'your passion,
But with your reason, you will come about
And think a faithful, and a frugal friend
To be preferred.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: A prodigal,
A tub without a bottom, as you termed him;
For which, I might return you a vow, or two,
And seal it with an oath of thankfulness,
I not repent it, neither have I cause, yet —

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Forehead of steel, and mouth of brass! hath impudence
Polished so gross a lie, and dar'st thou vent it?
Engine, composed of all mixed metals! hence,
I will not change a syllab, with thee, more,
Till I may meet thee, at a bar in court,
before thy judges.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Thither it must come,
Before I part with it, to you, or you, sir.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.p: his son entreats him. I will not hear thee.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Sir, your ear to me, though.
Not that I see through his perplexed plots,
And hidden ends, nor that my parts depend
Upon the unwinding this so knotted skein,
Do I beseech your patience. Unto me
He hath confessed the trust.

sp.speaker: P. ●●.
sp.p: Stand up to him, and confront him.

sp.speaker: P· iu.
sp.l: To me, even now, and here,
Canst thou deny it?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Can I eat or drink?
Sleep, wake, or dream? arise, sit, go, or stand?
Do any thing that's natural?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Yes, lie:
It seems thou canst, and perjure: that is natural!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: O me! what times are these! of frontless carriage ▪
An egg o'the same nest! the father's bird!
It runs in a blood, I see!

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: With noise, I must have witness.
Where is your witness? you can produce witness?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: As if my testimony were not twenty,
Balanced with thine?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: So say all prodigals,
Sick of self-love, but that's not law, young Scattergood.
I live by law.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Why? if thou hast a conscience,
That is a thousand witnesses.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: No, court,
Grants out a writ of summons, for the conscience,
That I know, nor subpoena, nor attachment.
I must have witness, and of your producing,
Ere this can come to hearing, and it must
Be heard on oath, and witness.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: Come forth, Thom,
he produceth Thom. speak what thou heardest, the truth, and the whole truth,
And nothing but the truth. What said this varlet?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sir, he said
It was a trust! an act, the which your father
Had will to alter: but his tender breast
Would not permit to see the heir defrauded;
And like an alien, thrust out of the blood.
The laws forbid that he should give consent
To such a civil slaughter of a son —

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: And talked of a gratuity to be given,
And aid unto the charges of the suit;
Which he was to maintain, in his own name,
But for my use, he said.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And he would milk Pecunia, and draw down
Her cream, before you got the trust, again.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Your ears are in my pocket, knave, go shake 'em,
The little while you have them.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: You do trust
To your great purse.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: I ha' you in a pursenet,
good master picklock, with your worming brain,
And wriggling engine-head of maintenance,
Which I shall see you hole with, very shortly.
A fine round head, when those two legs are off,
To trundle through a pillory. You are sure
You heard him speak this?

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: I'll prove yours maintenance, and combination,
And sue you all.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Do, do, my gowned vulture,
Crop in reversion: I shall see you quoited
Over the bar, as bargemen do their billets.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: This 'tis, when men repent of their good deeds,
And would ha'hem in again — they are almost mad!
But I forgive their Lucida intervalla.
O, Lickfinger? come hither. Where's my writing? Picklock spies Lickfinger, and asks him aside for the writing.

div.head: Act. v. scene. iii.
div.stage: Lickfinger. to them.

sp.l: I sent it you, together with your keys,

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: By the porter, that came for it, from you,
And by the token, you had given me the keys,
And bade me bring it.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: Why did you send a countermand?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: You, or some other you, you put in trust.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Your trust's another self, you know,
And without trust, and your trust, how should he
Take notice of your keys, or of my charge.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: I know he was a porter,
And a sealed porter for he bore the badge
On breast, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: I am lost! A plot! I sent it!

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Why! and I sent it by the man you sent
Whom else, I had not trusted.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.l: Plague o'your trust. picklock goes out.
I am trussed up among you.

sp.speaker: Pic.
sp.p: In mine own halter, I have made the noose.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: A writing, sir,young Peny-boy discovers it, to his father to be his plot of sending for it by the porter, and that he is in possession of the deed.
He sent for't by a token, I was bringing it:
But that he sent a porter, and he seemed
A man of decent carriage.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: 'Twas good fortune!
To cheat the cheater, was no cheat, but justice,
Put off your rags, and be yourself again,
This act of piety, and good affection,
Hath partly reconciled me to you.

sp.speaker: P. c.
sp.l: No vows, no promises: too much protestation
Makes that suspected oft, we would persuade.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.p: elder Peny-boy startles at the news. hear you the news?

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.p: The office is down, how should we?

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Stark staring mad, your brother,
H'has almost killed his maid.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: But that she's cat-lived, and squirrel-limbed,
With throwing bedstaffs at her: h'has set wide
His outer doors, and now keeps open house,
For all the passers by to see his justice:
First, he has apprehended his two dogs,
As being o'the plot to cozen him:
And there he sits like an old worm of the peace,
Wrapped up in furs at a square table, screwing,
Examining, and committing the poor curs,
To two old cases of close stools, as prisons;
The one of which, he calls his Lollard's tower,
Th'other his blockhouse, 'cause his two dogs names
Are block, and Lollard.

sp.speaker: P. iu.
sp.l: This would be brave matter
Unto the jeerers.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: Ay, if so the subject
Were not so wretched.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Sure, I met them all,
I think, upon that quest.

sp.speaker: P. Ca.
sp.l: I'faith, like enough ▪
The vicious still are swift to show their natures.
I'll thither too, but with another aim,
If all succeed well, and my simples take.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Iv.
div.stage: he is seen sitting at his table with papers before him. Peniboy. Sen. porter.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: They are forthcoming, sir,
Or coming forth at least.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: The rogue is drunk,
Since I committed them to his charge. Come hither,
he smells him. near me, yet nearer; breath upon me. Wine!
Wine, o'my worship! sack! Canary sack!
Could not your badge ha' been drunk with fulsome ale?
Or beer? the porter's element? but sack!

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am not drunk, we had, sir, but one pint,
An honest carrier, and myself.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Sir, I did give it him.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: What? and spend sixpence!
A frock spend sixpence! sixpence!

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Once in a year, sir,

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: In seven years, varlet! Know'st thou what thou hast done?
What a consumption thou hast made of a state?
It might please heaven, (A lusty knave and young)
To let thee live some seventy years longer.
Till thou art fourscore, and ten; perhaps, a hundred.
Say seventy years ▪ how many times seven in seventy?
Why, seven times ten, is ten times seven, mark me,
I will demonstrate to thee on my fingers,
Sixpence in seven year (Use upon use)
Grows in that first seven year, to be a twelvepence.
That, in the next, two-shillings; the third foure-shillings;
The fourth seven year, eight-shillings; the fifth, sixteen:
The sixth, two and thirty; the seventh, three-pound four,
The eighth, six pound, and eight; the ninth, twelve pound sixteen;
And the tenth seven, five and twenty pound,
Twelve shillings. This thou art fallen from, by thy riot!
Shouldst thou live seventy years, by spending sixpence,
Once i'the seven: but in a day to waste it!
There is a sum that number cannot reach!
Out o'my house, thou pest of prodigality!
Seed of consumption! hence, a wicked keeper
Is oft worse than the prisoners. There's thy penny,
Four tokens for thee. Out, away. My dogs,
May yet be innocent, and honest. If not,
I have an entrapping question, or two more,
To put unto 'em, a cross interrogatory,
And I shall catch 'em; Lollard? Peace,
What whispering was that you had with mortgage,he calls forth Lollard, and examines him.
When you last licked her feet? The truth now. Ha?
Did you smell she was going? Put down that. And not,
Not to return? You are silent. good. And, when
Leaped you on statute? As she went forth? Consent.
There was consent, as she was going forth.
'Twould have been fitter at her coming home,he commits him again.
But you knew that she would not? To your tower,
You are cunning, are you? I will meet your craft.
Block, show your face, leave your caresses, tell me,calls forth block, and examines him.
And tell me truly, what affronts do you know
Were done Pecunia? that she left my house?
None, say you so? not that you know? or will know?
I fear me, I shall find you an obstinate cur.
Why, did your fellow Lollard cry this morning?
'Cause Broker kicked him? why did Broker kick him?
Because he pissed against my lady's gown?
Why, that was no affront? no? no distaste?
You knew of none. You're a dissembling tike,commits him.
To your hole, again, your blockhouse. Lollard, arise,
Where did you lift your leg up, last? 'gainst what? Lollard is called again.
Are you struck dummerer now? and whine for mercy?
Whose kirtle was't, you gnawed too? Mistress bands?
And Waxe's stockings? who did? Block bescumber
Statutes white suit? with the parchment lace there?
And broker's satin doublet? all will out.
They had offence, offence enough to quit me.
block is summoned the second time. appear block, fough, 'tis manifest. He shows it,
Should he forswear't, make all the affidavits,
Against it, that he could afore the bench,
And twenty juries; he would be convinced.
he is remanded -he bears an air about him, doth confess it!
To prison again, close prison. Not you Lollard,
You may enjoy the liberty o'the house,
Lollard has the liberty of the house. and yet there is a quirk come in my head,
For which I must commit you too, and close,
Do not repine, it will be better for you.

div.head: enter the jeerers.act. v. scene. Ii.
div.stage: Cymbal. Fitton. Shunfield. Almanach. Madrigal. Peny-boy. Sen. Lickfinger.

sp.l: This is enough to make the dogs mad too,
Let's in upon him.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: How now? what's the matter?
Come you to force the prisoners? make a rescue?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: We come to bail your dogs.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: They are not bailable,
They stand committed without bail, or mainprize,
Your bail cannot be taken.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Then the truth is,
We come to vex you.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: A bated usurer will be good flesh.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Who is the butcher,
Amongst you, that is come to cut my throat?

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: You would die a calf's death fain: but 'tis an ox's,
Is meant you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: To be fairly knocked o'the head.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: With a good jeer or two.

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: And from your jawbone,
Don Assinigo?

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: Shunfield, a jeer, you have it.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: I do confess a washing blow? but snarl,
You that might play the third dog, for your teeth,
You ha' no money now?

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.p: Nor you no office, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Cymbal,
A mighty jeer.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: Pox o'these true jests, I say.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He will turn the better jeerer.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Let's upon him,
And if we cannot jeer him down in wit,

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: We'll give him a broad side, first.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But such as will not keep your capitol?

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: You were wont to ha●your breams —

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ay, and now, and then,
An emblem, o'your self, an o'ergrown pike?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: You ha' made a shift
sp.p: To swallow twenty such poor jacks ere now.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: If he should come to feed upon poor-john?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Or turn pure jack-a-lent after all this?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Tut, he'll live like a grasshopper —

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.p: Or like a bear, with licking his own claws.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: Ay, if his dogs were away.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: He'll eat them, first,
While they are fat.

sp.speaker: Fit,
sp.l: Faith, and when they are gone,
Here's nothing to be seen beyond.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.l: Except
His kindred, spiders, natives of the soil.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Dust, he will ha' enough here, to breed fleas.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But, by that time, he'll ha' no blood to rear 'em.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: He will be as thin as a lantern, we shall see thorough him,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And his gut colon, tell his intestina —

sp.speaker: P. Se.
sp.l: Rogues, rascals (his dogs bark. baw waw)

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: He calls his dogs to his aid.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: O! they but rise at mention of his tripes.

sp.speaker: Cym.
sp.p: Let them alone, they do it not for him.

sp.speaker: Shu.
sp.l: Or for custom,
As commonly curs do, one for another.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: Arm, arm you, gentlemen jeerers, th'old canter
Is coming in upon you, with his forces,
The gentleman, that was the canter.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: A consumption,
Kills where he goes.

sp.speaker: Lic.
sp.l: See! the whole covey is scattered,they all run away.
'Beware,' beware the hawks. I love to see him fly.

div.head: Act. v. scene. Vi.
div.stage: Peny-boy. Ca. Peny-boy. Se. Peniboy. Iv. pecunia. Train.

sp.l: You see by this amazement, and distraction,
What your companions were, a poor, affrighted,
And guilty race of men, that dare to stand
No breath of truth: but conscious to themselves
Of their no-wit, or honesty, ran routed
At every panic terror themselves bred.
Where else, as confident as sounding brass,
